obscure technical issue.

00:06:06.780 --> 00:06:09.145
We weren't really interested
in that kind of case,

00:06:09.169 --> 00:06:11.558
and we thought this case
was much bigger than that.

00:06:11.582 --> 00:06:14.070
This was about scientific freedom,
medical progress,

00:06:14.094 --> 00:06:15.553
the rights of patients.

00:06:15.577 --> 00:06:18.680
So we decided we were going
to develop a case

00:06:18.704 --> 00:06:21.222
that was not like
your typical patent case --

00:06:21.603 --> 00:06:23.485
more like a civil rights case.

00:06:24.714 --> 00:06:27.556
We set out to identify
a gene-patent holder

00:06:27.580 --> 00:06:30.365
that was vigorously enforcing its patents

00:06:30.389 --> 00:06:33.683
and then to organize a broad coalition
of plaintiffs and experts

00:06:33.707 --> 00:06:35.597
that could tell the court

00:06:35.621 --> 00:06:40.010
about all the ways that these patents
were harming patients and innovation.

00:06:41.362 --> 00:06:44.484
We found the prime candidate
to sue in Myriad Genetics,

00:06:44.508 --> 00:06:47.363
a company that's based
in Salt Lake City, Utah.

00:06:48.676 --> 00:06:50.926
Myriad held patents on two genes,

00:06:50.950 --> 00:06:54.271
the BRCA1 and the BRCA2 genes.

00:06:55.108 --> 00:06:57.842
Women with certain mutations
along these genes

00:06:57.866 --> 00:07:00.492
are considered to be
at a significantly increased risk

00:07:00.516 --> 00:07:02.461
of developing breast and ovarian cancer.

00:07:03.792 --> 00:07:05.672
Myriad had used its patents to maintain

00:07:05.696 --> 00:07:09.905
a complete monopoly on BRCA testing
in the United States.

00:07:10.502 --> 00:07:14.690
It had forced multiple labs
that were offering BRCA testing to stop.

00:07:14.714 --> 00:07:16.873
It charged a lot of money for its test --

00:07:16.897 --> 00:07:18.580
over 3,000 dollars.

00:07:19.047 --> 00:07:21.382
It had stopped sharing its clinical data

00:07:21.406 --> 00:07:23.693
with the international
scientific community.

00:07:24.480 --> 00:07:26.383
And perhaps worst of all,

00:07:26.407 --> 00:07:28.843
for a period of several years,

00:07:28.867 --> 00:07:32.580
Myriad refused to update its test
to include additional mutations

00:07:32.604 --> 00:07:36.225
that had been identified
by a team of researchers in France.

00:07:36.932 --> 00:07:39.440
It has been estimated
that during that period,

00:07:39.464 --> 00:07:40.837
for several years,

00:07:40.861 --> 00:07:44.613
as many as 12 percent of women
undergoing testing

00:07:44.637 --> 00:07:47.039
received the wrong answer --

00:07:48.335 --> 00:07:52.104
a negative test result
that should have been positive.

00:07:53.443 --> 00:07:55.184
This is Kathleen Maxian.

00:07:56.130 --> 00:07:59.387
Kathleen's sister Eileen
developed breast cancer at age 40

00:07:59.411 --> 00:08:01.251
and she was tested by Myriad.

00:08:01.990 --> 00:08:03.716
The test was negative.

00:08:03.740 --> 00:08:05.266
The family was relieved.

00:08:05.290 --> 00:08:09.078
That meant that Eileen's cancer
most likely didn't run in the family,

00:08:09.102 --> 00:08:12.117
and that other members of her family
didn't need to be tested.

00:08:12.801 --> 00:08:14.031
But two years later,

00:08:14.055 --> 00:08:18.115
Kathleen was diagnosed
with advanced-stage ovarian cancer.

00:08:18.885 --> 00:08:22.757
It turned out that Kathleen's sister
was among the 12 percent

00:08:22.781 --> 00:08:25.650
who received a false-negative test result.

00:08:26.305 --> 00:08:29.394
Had Eileen received the proper result,

00:08:29.418 --> 00:08:31.791
Kathleen would have then been tested,

00:08:31.815 --> 00:08:34.728
and her ovarian cancer
could have been prevented.

00:08:36.776 --> 00:08:38.040
Once we settled on Myriad,

00:08:38.064 --> 00:08:41.949
we then had to form a coalition
of plaintiffs and experts

00:08:41.973 --> 00:08:44.061
that could illuminate these problems.

00:08:44.085 --> 00:08:46.657
We ended up with 20
highly committed plaintiffs:

00:08:47.283 --> 00:08:48.821
genetic counselors,

00:08:48.845 --> 00:08:52.204
geneticists who had received
cease and desist letters,

00:08:52.863 --> 00:08:54.712
advocacy organizations,

00:08:55.490 --> 00:08:58.555
four major scientific organizations
that collectively represented

00:08:58.579 --> 00:09:02.109
more than 150,000 scientists
and medical professionals,

00:09:02.713 --> 00:09:06.010
and individual women who either
couldn't afford Myriad's test,

00:09:06.034 --> 00:09:09.038
or who wanted to obtain
a second opinion but could not,

00:09:09.062 --> 00:09:10.806
as a result of the patents.

00:09:12.273 --> 00:09:15.713
One of the major challenges
we had in preparing the case

00:09:15.737 --> 00:09:18.603
was figuring out how best
to communicate the science.

00:09:19.037 --> 00:09:22.868
So in order to argue that what Myriad did
was not an invention,

00:09:22.892 --> 00:09:26.169
and that isolated BRCA genes
were products of nature,

00:09:27.082 --> 00:09:29.795
we had to explain a couple
of basic concepts, like:

00:09:29.819 --> 00:09:31.963
What's a gene? What's DNA?

00:09:31.987 --> 00:09:35.703
How is DNA isolated,
and why isn't that an invention?

00:09:37.126 --> 00:09:40.988
We spent hours and hours
with our plaintiffs and experts,

00:09:41.012 --> 00:09:43.948
trying to come up with ways
of explaining these concepts

00:09:43.972 --> 00:09:45.515
simply yet accurately.

00:09:46.264 --> 00:09:49.596
And we ended up relying heavily
on the use of metaphors,

00:09:49.620 --> 00:09:50.776
like gold.

00:09:51.747 --> 00:09:54.031
So isolating DNA --

00:09:54.055 --> 00:09:56.555
it's like extracting gold from a mountain

00:09:57.063 --> 00:09:59.079
or taking it out of a stream bed.

00:09:59.103 --> 00:10:02.777
You might be able to patent
the process for mining the gold,

00:10:02.801 --> 00:10:04.882
but you can't patent the gold itself.

00:10:05.887 --> 00:10:08.630
It might've taken a lot
of hard work and effort

00:10:08.654 --> 00:10:10.514
to dig the gold out of the mountain;

00:10:11.085 --> 00:10:13.366
you still can't patent it,
it's still gold.

00:10:13.390 --> 00:10:15.146
And the gold, once it's extracted,

00:10:15.170 --> 00:10:17.258
can clearly be used
for all sorts of things

00:10:17.282 --> 00:10:20.018
that it couldn't be used
for when it was in the mountain;

00:10:20.042 --> 00:10:22.224
you can make jewelry
out of it for example --

00:10:22.248 --> 00:10:24.413
still can't patent the gold,
it's still gold.

00:10:25.322 --> 00:10:29.176
So now it's 2009,
and we're ready to file our case.

00:10:30.244 --> 00:10:33.739
We filed in federal court
in the Southern District of New York,

00:10:34.313 --> 00:10:37.679
and the case was randomly assigned
to Judge Robert Sweet.

00:10:38.557 --> 00:10:41.757
In March 2010, Judge Sweet
issued his opinion --

00:10:42.527 --> 00:10:44.385
152 pages --

00:10:44.792 --> 00:10:47.044
and a complete victory for our side.

00:10:47.922 --> 00:10:49.353
In reading the opinion,

00:10:49.377 --> 00:10:54.092
we could not get over how eloquently
he described the science in the case.

00:10:54.462 --> 00:10:57.233
I mean, our brief --
it was pretty good,

00:10:57.257 --> 00:10:58.824
but not this good.

00:10:59.736 --> 00:11:03.113
How did he develop such a deep
understanding of this issue

00:11:03.137 --> 00:11:04.297
in such a short time?

00:11:04.321 --> 00:11:07.929
We just could not comprehend
how this had happened.

00:11:07.953 --> 00:11:09.217
So it turned out,

00:11:09.241 --> 00:11:12.551
Judge Sweet's clerk
working for him at the time,

00:11:12.575 --> 00:11:14.055
was not just a lawyer --

00:11:14.079 --> 00:11:15.793
he was a scientist.

00:11:15.817 --> 00:11:17.415
He was not just a scientist --

00:11:17.439 --> 00:11:20.585
he had a PhD in molecular biology.

00:11:20.609 --> 00:11:22.360
(Laughter)

00:11:22.384 --> 00:11:24.959
What an incredible stroke of luck!

00:11:26.016 --> 00:11:27.316
Myriad then appealed

00:11:27.340 --> 00:11:29.835
to the US Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit.

00:11:30.454 --> 00:11:32.470
And here things got really interesting.

00:11:33.423 --> 00:11:36.483
First, in a pivotal moment of this case,

00:11:37.145 --> 00:11:39.776
the US government switched sides.

00:11:40.697 --> 00:11:44.446
So in the district court the government
submitted a brief on Myriad's side.

00:11:44.470 --> 00:11:49.598
But now in direct opposition
to its own patent office,

00:11:49.622 --> 00:11:52.330
the US government files a brief
that states that is has

00:11:52.354 --> 00:11:56.042
reconsidered this issue
in light of the district court's opinion,

00:11:56.066 --> 00:11:59.252
and has concluded that isolated DNA
is not patent eligible.

00:11:59.776 --> 00:12:01.587
This was a really big deal,

00:12:01.611 --> 00:12:03.173
totally unexpected.

00:12:04.731 --> 00:12:06.811
The Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit

00:12:06.835 --> 00:12:08.518
hears all patent cases,

00:12:08.542 --> 00:12:11.700
and it has a reputation for being
very, very pro-patent.

00:12:12.263 --> 00:12:14.689
So even with this remarkable development,

00:12:14.713 --> 00:12:16.392
we expected to lose.

00:12:16.416 --> 00:12:17.763
And we did.

00:12:18.347 --> 00:12:19.499
Sort of.

00:12:20.315 --> 00:12:22.902
Ends up split decision, 2 to 1.

00:12:23.701 --> 00:12:26.197
But the two judges who ruled against us,

00:12:26.221 --> 00:12:28.462
did so for completely different reasons.

00:12:29.233 --> 00:12:31.059
The first one, Judge Lourie,

00:12:31.083 --> 00:12:34.098
made up his own novel,
biological theory --

00:12:34.122 --> 00:12:35.290
totally wrong.

00:12:35.314 --> 00:12:36.325
(Laughter)

00:12:36.349 --> 00:12:38.567
He decided Myriad had created
a new chemical --

00:12:38.591 --> 00:12:40.456
made absolutely no sense.

00:12:40.480 --> 00:12:43.266
Myriad didn't even argue this,
so it came out of the blue.

00:12:43.590 --> 00:12:45.567
The other, Judge Moore,

00:12:45.591 --> 00:12:49.469
said she basically agreed with us
that isolated DNA is a product of nature.

00:12:49.945 --> 00:12:53.278
But she's like, "I don't want
to shake up the biotech industry."

00:12:54.206 --> 00:12:56.778
The third, Judge Bryson,

00:12:57.191 --> 00:12:58.407
agreed with us.

00:12:59.708 --> 00:13:02.239
So now we sought review
by the Supreme Court.

00:13:02.263 --> 00:13:04.966
And when you petition the Supreme Court,

00:13:04.990 --> 00:13:08.112
you have to present a question
that you want the Court to answer.

00:13:08.492 --> 00:13:12.219
Usually these questions take the form
of a super-long paragraph,

00:13:12.243 --> 00:13:15.266
like a whole page long
with lots and lots of clauses,

00:13:15.290 --> 00:13:17.747
"wherein this" and "therefore that."

00:13:18.252 --> 00:13:22.159
We submitted perhaps
the shortest question presented ever.

00:13:23.270 --> 00:13:24.483
Four words:

00:13:26.178 --> 00:13:28.229
Are human genes patentable?

00:13:28.880 --> 00:13:31.704
Now when Chris first asked me
what I thought of these words,

00:13:31.728 --> 00:13:33.102
I said, "Well, I don't know.

00:13:33.126 --> 00:13:36.293
I think you have to say,
'Is isolated DNA patentable?'"

00:13:36.926 --> 00:13:38.095
"Nope.

00:13:38.445 --> 00:13:43.066
I want the justices to have
the very same reaction that I had

00:13:43.090 --> 00:13:46.177
when you brought this issue
to me seven years ago."

00:13:46.854 --> 00:13:49.011
Well, I certainly couldn't
argue with that.

00:13:49.939 --> 00:13:52.822
The Supreme Court only hears
about one percent

00:13:52.846 --> 00:13:54.512
of the cases that it receives,

00:13:54.536 --> 00:13:56.127
and it agreed to hear ours.

00:13:57.730 --> 00:14:01.857
The day of the oral argument arrives,
and it was really, really exciting --

00:14:01.881 --> 00:14:03.316
long line of people outside,

00:14:03.340 --> 00:14:06.104
people had been standing in line
since 2:30 in the morning

00:14:06.128 --> 00:14:07.862
to try to get into the courthouse.

00:14:07.886 --> 00:14:09.857
Two breast cancer organizations,

00:14:09.881 --> 00:14:11.549
Breast Cancer Action and FORCE,

00:14:11.573 --> 00:14:14.274
had organized a demonstration
on the courthouse steps.

00:14:15.190 --> 00:14:18.060
Chris and I sat quietly in the hallway,

00:14:18.734 --> 00:14:21.748
moments before he was to walk in and argue

00:14:21.772 --> 00:14:24.088
the most important case of his career.

00:14:24.723 --> 00:14:27.102
I was clearly more nervous than he was.

00:14:28.054 --> 00:14:32.814
But any remaining panic subsided
as I walked into the courtroom

00:14:32.838 --> 00:14:35.651
and looked around
at a sea of friendly faces:

00:14:36.017 --> 00:14:37.782
our individual women clients

00:14:37.806 --> 00:14:40.247
who had shared their
deeply personal stories,

00:14:41.168 --> 00:14:44.794
the geneticists who had taken huge chunks
of time out of their busy careers

00:14:44.818 --> 00:14:46.643
to dedicate themselves to this fight

00:14:47.080 --> 00:14:49.659
and representatives from a diverse array

00:14:49.683 --> 00:14:51.570
of medical, patient advocacy,

00:14:51.594 --> 00:14:53.670
environmental and religious organizations,

00:14:53.694 --> 00:14:57.226
who had submitted friend of the court
briefs in the case.

00:14:58.567 --> 00:15:01.592
Also in the room were three leaders
of the Human Genome Project,

00:15:01.616 --> 00:15:04.288
including the co-discoverer
of DNA himself,

00:15:04.312 --> 00:15:05.602
James Watson,

00:15:05.626 --> 00:15:07.772
who had submitted a brief to the court,

00:15:07.796 --> 00:15:11.307
where he referred
to gene patenting as "lunacy."

00:15:11.331 --> 00:15:13.179
(Laughter)

00:15:13.203 --> 00:15:16.840
The diversity of the communities
represented in this room

00:15:16.864 --> 00:15:20.305
and the contributions each had made
to make this day a reality

00:15:20.329 --> 00:15:22.626
spoke volumes to what was at stake.

00:15:23.344 --> 00:15:25.557
The argument itself was riveting.

00:15:26.163 --> 00:15:27.826
Chris argued brilliantly.

00:15:27.850 --> 00:15:29.095
But for me,

00:15:29.119 --> 00:15:32.883
the most thrilling aspect was watching
the Supreme Court justices grapple

00:15:32.907 --> 00:15:34.476
with isolated DNA,

00:15:34.500 --> 00:15:37.726
through a series of colorful analogies
and feisty exchanges,

00:15:37.750 --> 00:15:41.090
very much the same way
as our legal team had done

00:15:41.114 --> 00:15:42.804
for the past seven years.

00:15:43.624 --> 00:15:46.280
Justice Kagan likened isolating DNA

00:15:46.304 --> 00:15:49.080
to extracting a medicinal plant
from the Amazon.

00:15:50.474 --> 00:15:54.484
Justice Roberts distinguished it
from carving a baseball bat from a tree.

00:15:55.953 --> 00:15:58.435
And in one of my absolutely
favorite moments,

00:15:58.459 --> 00:16:03.728
Justice Sotomayor proclaimed isolated DNA
to be "just nature sitting there."

00:16:03.752 --> 00:16:04.852
(Laughter)

00:16:05.276 --> 00:16:08.151
We felt pretty confident
leaving the courtroom that day,

00:16:08.175 --> 00:16:11.181
but I could never have
anticipated the outcome:

00:16:12.532 --> 00:16:14.039
nine to zero.

00:16:14.983 --> 00:16:18.705
"A naturally occurring DNA segment
is a product of nature,

00:16:18.729 --> 00:16:21.776
and not patent-eligible merely because
it has been isolated.

00:16:22.352 --> 00:16:23.699
And furthermore,

00:16:23.723 --> 00:16:26.268
Myriad did not create anything."

00:16:28.118 --> 00:16:30.114
Within 24 hours of the decision,

00:16:30.138 --> 00:16:31.530
five labs had announced

00:16:31.554 --> 00:16:34.568
that they would begin to offer testing
for the BRCA genes.

00:16:35.107 --> 00:16:38.590
Some of them promised to offer the tests
at a lower price than Myriad's.

00:16:39.100 --> 00:16:42.020
Some promised to provide
a more comprehensive test

00:16:42.044 --> 00:16:43.727
than the one Myriad was offering.

00:16:44.448 --> 00:16:47.286
But of course the decision
goes far beyond Myriad.

00:16:47.310 --> 00:16:51.706
It ends a 25-year practice
of allowing patents on human genes

00:16:51.730 --> 00:16:52.937
in the United States.

00:16:53.341 --> 00:16:58.034
It clears a significant barrier
to biomedical discovery and innovation.

00:16:58.442 --> 00:17:03.343
And it helps to ensure that patients
like Abigail, Kathleen and Eileen

00:17:03.367 --> 00:17:05.523
have access to the tests that they need.

00:17:06.949 --> 00:17:10.164
A few weeks after the court
issued its decision,

00:17:10.188 --> 00:17:12.448
I received a small package in the mail.

00:17:13.204 --> 00:17:14.811
It was from Bob Cook-Deegan,

00:17:14.835 --> 00:17:17.104
a professor at Duke University

00:17:17.128 --> 00:17:20.352
and one the very first people
Chris and I went to visit

00:17:20.376 --> 00:17:23.075
when we started to consider
whether to bring this case.

00:17:23.991 --> 00:17:26.800
I opened it up to find
a small stuffed animal.

00:17:28.302 --> 00:17:31.261
(Laughter)

00:17:33.526 --> 00:17:35.854
We took a big risk in taking this case.

00:17:36.680 --> 00:17:39.190
Part of what gave us the courage
to take that risk

00:17:39.214 --> 00:17:41.652
was knowing that we were doing
the right thing.

00:17:42.037 --> 00:17:45.767
The process took nearly eight years
from the start to finish,

00:17:45.791 --> 00:17:48.012
with many twists and turns along the way.

00:17:48.536 --> 00:17:50.227
A little luck certainly helped,

00:17:50.846 --> 00:17:53.658
but it was the communities
that we bridged,

00:17:53.682 --> 00:17:55.773
the alliances that we created,

00:17:55.797 --> 00:17:57.217
that made pigs fly.

00:17:57.760 --> 00:17:58.916
Thank you.

00:17:58.940 --> 00:18:04.454
(Applause)

title: A robot that runs and swims like a salamander
transcript: This is Pleurobot. Pleurobot is a robot that we designed to closely mimic a salamander species called Pleurodeles waltl. Pleurobot can walk, as you can see here, and as you'll see later, it can also swim.So you might ask, why did we design this robot? And in fact, this robot has been designed as a scientific tool for neuroscience. Indeed, we designed it together with neurobiologists to understand how animals move, and especially how the spinal cord controls locomotion. But the more I work in biorobotics, the more I'm really impressed by animal locomotion. If you think of a dolphin swimming or a cat running or jumping around, or even us as humans, when you go jogging or play tennis, we do amazing things. And in fact, our nervous system solves a very, very complex control problem. It has to coordinate more or less 200 muscles perfectly, because if the coordination is bad, we fall over or we do bad locomotion. And my goal is to understand how this works.There are four main components behind animal locomotion. The first component is just the body, and in fact we should never underestimate to what extent the biomechanics already simplify locomotion in animals. Then you have the spinal cord, and in the spinal cord you find reflexes, multiple reflexes that create a sensorimotor coordination loop between neural activity in the spinal cord and mechanical activity. A third component are central pattern generators. These are very interesting circuits in the spinal cord of vertebrate animals that can generate, by themselves, very coordinated rhythmic patterns of activity while receiving only very simple input signals. And these input signals coming from descending modulation from higher parts of the brain, like the motor cortex, the cerebellum, the basal ganglia, will all modulate activity of the spinal cord while we do locomotion. But what's interesting is to what extent just a low-level component, the spinal cord, together with the body, already solve a big part of the locomotion problem. You probably know it by the fact that you can cut the head off a chicken, it can still run for a while, showing that just the lower part, spinal cord and body, already solve a big part of locomotion.Now, understanding how this works is very complex, because first of all, recording activity in the spinal cord is very difficult. It's much easier to implant electrodes in the motor cortex than in the spinal cord, because it's protected by the vertebrae. Especially in humans, very hard to do. A second difficulty is that locomotion is really due to a very complex and very dynamic interaction between these four components. So it's very hard to find out what's the role of each over time. This is where biorobots like Pleurobot and mathematical models can really help.So what's biorobotics? Biorobotics is a very active field of research in robotics where people want to take inspiration from animals to make robots to go outdoors, like service robots or search and rescue robots or field robots. And the big goal here is to take inspiration from animals to make robots that can handle complex terrain — stairs, mountains, forests, places where robots still have difficulties and where animals can do a much better job. The robot can be a wonderful scientific tool as well. There are some very nice projects where robots are used, like a scientific tool for neuroscience, for biomechanics or for hydrodynamics. And this is exactly the purpose of Pleurobot. So what we do in my lab is to collaborate with neurobiologists like Jean-Marie Cabelguen, a neurobiologist in Bordeaux in France, and we want to make spinal cord models and validate them on robots. And here we want to start simple.So it's good to start with simple animals like lampreys, which are very primitive fish, and then gradually go toward more complex locomotion, like in salamanders, but also in cats and in humans, in mammals. And here, a robot becomes an interesting tool to validate our models. And in fact, for me, Pleurobot is a kind of dream becoming true. Like, more or less 20 years ago I was already working on a computer making simulations of lamprey and salamander locomotion during my PhD. But I always knew that my simulations were just approximations. Like, simulating the physics in water or with mud or with complex ground, it's very hard to simulate that properly on a computer. Why not have a real robot and real physics? So among all these animals, one of my favorites is the salamander. You might ask why, and it's because as an amphibian, it's a really key animal from an evolutionary point of view. It makes a wonderful link between swimming, as you find it in eels or fish, and quadruped locomotion, as you see in mammals, in cats and humans. And in fact, the modern salamander is very close to the first terrestrial vertebrate, so it's almost a living fossil, which gives us access to our ancestor, the ancestor to all terrestrial tetrapods.So the salamander swims by doing what's called an anguilliform swimming gait, so they propagate a nice traveling wave of muscle activity from head to tail. And if you place the salamander on the ground, it switches to what's called a walking trot gait. In this case, you have nice periodic activation of the limbs which are very nicely coordinated with this standing wave undulation of the body, and that's exactly the gait that you are seeing here on Pleurobot. Now, one thing which is very surprising and fascinating in fact is the fact that all this can be generated just by the spinal cord and the body. So if you take a decerebrated salamander — it's not so nice but you remove the head — and if you electrically stimulate the spinal cord, at low level of stimulation this will induce a walking-like gait. If you stimulate a bit more, the gait accelerates. And at some point, there's a threshold, and automatically, the animal switches to swimming. This is amazing. Just changing the global drive, as if you are pressing the gas pedal of descending modulation to your spinal cord, makes a complete switch between two very different gaits. And in fact, the same has been observed in cats. If you stimulate the spinal cord of a cat, you can switch between walk, trot and gallop. Or in birds, you can make a bird switch between walking, at a low level of stimulation, and flapping its wings at high-level stimulation. And this really shows that the spinal cord is a very sophisticated locomotion controller.So we studied salamander locomotion in more detail, and we had in fact access to a very nice X-ray video machine from Professor Martin Fischer in Jena University in Germany. And thanks to that, you really have an amazing machine to record all the bone motion in great detail. That's what we did. So we basically figured out which bones are important for us and collected their motion in 3D. And what we did is collect a whole database of motions, both on ground and in water, to really collect a whole database of motor behaviors that a real animal can do. And then our job as roboticists was to replicate that in our robot. So we did a whole optimization process to find out the right structure, where to place the motors, how to connect them together, to be able to replay these motions as well as possible. And this is how Pleurobot came to life.So let's look at how close it is to the real animal. So what you see here is almost a direct comparison between the walking of the real animal and the Pleurobot. You can see that we have almost a one-to-one exact replay of the walking gait. If you go backwards and slowly, you see it even better. But even better, we can do swimming. So for that we have a dry suit that we put all over the robot —(Laughter)and then we can go in water and start replaying the swimming gaits. And here, we were very happy, because this is difficult to do. The physics of interaction are complex. Our robot is much bigger than a small animal, so we had to do what's called dynamic scaling of the frequencies to make sure we had the same interaction physics. But you see at the end, we have a very close match, and we were very, very happy with this. So let's go to the spinal cord. So here what we did with Jean-Marie Cabelguen is model the spinal cord circuits. And what's interesting is that the salamander has kept a very primitive circuit, which is very similar to the one we find in the lamprey, this primitive eel-like fish, and it looks like during evolution, new neural oscillators have been added to control the limbs, to do the leg locomotion. And we know where these neural oscillators are but what we did was to make a mathematical model to see how they should be coupled to allow this transition between the two very different gaits. And we tested that on board of a robot.And this is how it looks. So what you see here is a previous version of Pleurobot that's completely controlled by our spinal cord model programmed on board of the robot. And the only thing we do is send to the robot through a remote control the two descending signals it normally should receive from the upper part of the brain. And what's interesting is, by playing with these signals, we can completely control speed, heading and type of gait. For instance, when we stimulate at a low level, we have the walking gait, and at some point, if we stimulate a lot, very rapidly it switches to the swimming gait. And finally, we can also do turning very nicely by just stimulating more one side of the spinal cord than the other. And I think it's really beautiful how nature has distributed control to really give a lot of responsibility to the spinal cord so that the upper part of the brain doesn't need to worry about every muscle. It just has to worry about this high-level modulation, and it's really the job of the spinal cord to coordinate all the muscles.So now let's go to cat locomotion and the importance of biomechanics. So this is another project where we studied cat biomechanics, and we wanted to see how much the morphology helps locomotion. And we found three important criteria in the properties, basically, of the limbs. The first one is that a cat limb more or less looks like a pantograph-like structure. So a pantograph is a mechanical structure which keeps the upper segment and the lower segments always parallel. So a simple geometrical system that kind of coordinates a bit the internal movement of the segments. A second property of cat limbs is that they are very lightweight. Most of the muscles are in the trunk, which is a good idea, because then the limbs have low inertia and can be moved very rapidly. The last final important property is this very elastic behavior of the cat limb, so to handle impacts and forces. And this is how we designed Cheetah-Cub.So let's invite Cheetah-Cub onstage. So this is Peter Eckert, who does his PhD on this robot, and as you see, it's a cute little robot. It looks a bit like a toy, but it was really used as a scientific tool to investigate these properties of the legs of the cat. So you see, it's very compliant, very lightweight, and also very elastic, so you can easily press it down and it will not break. It will just jump, in fact. And this very elastic property is also very important. And you also see a bit these properties of these three segments of the leg as pantograph.Now, what's interesting is that this quite dynamic gait is obtained purely in open loop, meaning no sensors, no complex feedback loops. And that's interesting, because it means that just the mechanics already stabilized this quite rapid gait, and that really good mechanics already basically simplify locomotion. To the extent that we can even disturb a bit locomotion, as you will see in the next video, where we can for instance do some exercise where we have the robot go down a step, and the robot will not fall over, which was a surprise for us. This is a small perturbation. I was expecting the robot to immediately fall over, because there are no sensors, no fast feedback loop. But no, just the mechanics stabilized the gait, and the robot doesn't fall over. Obviously, if you make the step bigger, and if you have obstacles, you need the full control loops and reflexes and everything. But what's important here is that just for small perturbation, the mechanics are right. And I think this is a very important message from biomechanics and robotics to neuroscience, saying don't underestimate to what extent the body already helps locomotion.Now, how does this relate to human locomotion? Clearly, human locomotion is more complex than cat and salamander locomotion, but at the same time, the nervous system of humans is very similar to that of other vertebrates. And especially the spinal cord is also the key controller for locomotion in humans. That's why, if there's a lesion of the spinal cord, this has dramatic effects. The person can become paraplegic or tetraplegic. This is because the brain loses this communication with the spinal cord. Especially, it loses this descending modulation to initiate and modulate locomotion. So a big goal of neuroprosthetics is to be able to reactivate that communication using electrical or chemical stimulations. And there are several teams in the world that do exactly that, especially at EPFL. My colleagues Grégoire Courtine and Silvestro Micera, with whom I collaborate.But to do this properly, it's very important to understand how the spinal cord works, how it interacts with the body, and how the brain communicates with the spinal cord. This is where the robots and models that I've presented today will hopefully play a key role towards these very important goals.Thank you.(Applause)Bruno Giussani: Auke, I've seen in your lab other robots that do things like swim in pollution and measure the pollution while they swim. But for this one, you mentioned in your talk, like a side project, search and rescue, and it does have a camera on its nose.Auke Ijspeert: Absolutely. So the robot — We have some spin-off projects where we would like to use the robots to do search and rescue inspection, so this robot is now seeing you. And the big dream is to, if you have a difficult situation like a collapsed building or a building that is flooded, and this is very dangerous for a rescue team or even rescue dogs, why not send in a robot that can crawl around, swim, walk, with a camera onboard to do inspection and identify survivors and possibly create a communication link with the survivor.BG: Of course, assuming the survivors don't get scared by the shape of this.AI: Yeah, we should probably change the appearance quite a bit, because here I guess a survivor might die of a heart attack just of being worried that this would feed on you. But by changing the appearance and it making it more robust, I'm sure we can make a good tool out of it.BG: Thank you very much. Thank you and your team.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.718 --> 00:00:14.558
This is Pleurobot.

00:00:15.358 --> 00:00:18.974
Pleurobot is a robot that we designed
to closely mimic a salamander species

00:00:18.998 --> 00:00:20.398
called Pleurodeles waltl.

00:00:21.198 --> 00:00:23.454
Pleurobot can walk, as you can see here,

00:00:23.478 --> 00:00:25.518
and as you'll see later, it can also swim.

00:00:26.238 --> 00:00:28.429
So you might ask,
why did we design this robot?

00:00:28.918 --> 00:00:32.680
And in fact, this robot has been designed
as a scientific tool for neuroscience.

00:00:33.358 --> 00:00:35.854
Indeed, we designed it
together with neurobiologists

00:00:35.878 --> 00:00:37.774
to understand how animals move,

00:00:37.798 --> 00:00:40.558
and especially how the spinal cord
controls locomotion.

00:00:41.518 --> 00:00:43.214
But the more I work in biorobotics,

00:00:43.238 --> 00:00:45.619
the more I'm really impressed
by animal locomotion.

00:00:45.878 --> 00:00:50.174
If you think of a dolphin swimming
or a cat running or jumping around,

00:00:50.198 --> 00:00:51.774
or even us as humans,

00:00:51.798 --> 00:00:53.614
when you go jogging or play tennis,

00:00:53.638 --> 00:00:54.878
we do amazing things.

00:00:55.838 --> 00:00:59.974
And in fact, our nervous system solves
a very, very complex control problem.

00:00:59.998 --> 00:01:03.094
It has to coordinate
more or less 200 muscles perfectly,

00:01:03.118 --> 00:01:06.798
because if the coordination is bad,
we fall over or we do bad locomotion.

00:01:07.518 --> 00:01:10.238
And my goal is to understand
how this works.

00:01:11.118 --> 00:01:13.958
There are four main components
behind animal locomotion.

00:01:14.758 --> 00:01:16.694
The first component is just the body,

00:01:16.718 --> 00:01:18.694
and in fact we should never underestimate

00:01:18.718 --> 00:01:22.198
to what extent the biomechanics
already simplify locomotion in animals.

00:01:22.878 --> 00:01:24.334
Then you have the spinal cord,

00:01:24.358 --> 00:01:26.334
and in the spinal cord you find reflexes,

00:01:26.358 --> 00:01:29.814
multiple reflexes that create
a sensorimotor coordination loop

00:01:29.838 --> 00:01:33.318
between neural activity in the spinal cord
and mechanical activity.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.934
A third component
are central pattern generators.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:40.854
These are very interesting circuits
in the spinal cord of vertebrate animals

00:01:40.878 --> 00:01:42.494
that can generate, by themselves,

00:01:42.518 --> 00:01:45.254
very coordinated
rhythmic patterns of activity

00:01:45.278 --> 00:01:47.654
while receiving
only very simple input signals.

00:01:47.678 --> 00:01:48.894
And these input signals

00:01:48.918 --> 00:01:51.974
coming from descending modulation
from higher parts of the brain,

00:01:51.998 --> 00:01:54.694
like the motor cortex,
the cerebellum, the basal ganglia,

00:01:54.718 --> 00:01:56.854
will all modulate activity
of the spinal cord

00:01:56.878 --> 00:01:58.334
while we do locomotion.

00:01:58.358 --> 00:02:01.574
But what's interesting is to what extent
just a low-level component,

00:02:01.598 --> 00:02:03.534
the spinal cord, together with the body,

00:02:03.558 --> 00:02:06.014
already solve a big part
of the locomotion problem.

00:02:06.038 --> 00:02:09.460
You probably know it by the fact
that you can cut the head off a chicken,

00:02:09.490 --> 00:02:10.871
it can still run for a while,

00:02:10.895 --> 00:02:13.434
showing that just the lower part,
spinal cord and body,

00:02:13.458 --> 00:02:15.331
already solve a big part of locomotion.

00:02:15.355 --> 00:02:17.814
Now, understanding how this works
is very complex,

00:02:17.838 --> 00:02:19.134
because first of all,

00:02:19.158 --> 00:02:21.778
recording activity in the spinal cord
is very difficult.

00:02:21.802 --> 00:02:24.574
It's much easier to implant electrodes
in the motor cortex

00:02:24.598 --> 00:02:27.654
than in the spinal cord,
because it's protected by the vertebrae.

00:02:27.678 --> 00:02:29.494
Especially in humans, very hard to do.

00:02:29.518 --> 00:02:33.294
A second difficulty is that locomotion
is really due to a very complex

00:02:33.318 --> 00:02:36.374
and very dynamic interaction
between these four components.

00:02:36.398 --> 00:02:39.638
So it's very hard to find out
what's the role of each over time.

00:02:40.838 --> 00:02:44.574
This is where biorobots like Pleurobot
and mathematical models

00:02:44.598 --> 00:02:45.798
can really help.

00:02:47.438 --> 00:02:48.694
So what's biorobotics?

00:02:48.718 --> 00:02:51.454
Biorobotics is a very active field
of research in robotics

00:02:51.478 --> 00:02:53.934
where people want to
take inspiration from animals

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.414
to make robots to go outdoors,

00:02:56.438 --> 00:02:59.094
like service robots
or search and rescue robots

00:02:59.118 --> 00:03:00.318
or field robots.

00:03:00.838 --> 00:03:03.534
And the big goal here
is to take inspiration from animals

00:03:03.558 --> 00:03:05.894
to make robots that can handle
complex terrain --

00:03:05.918 --> 00:03:07.534
stairs, mountains, forests,

00:03:07.558 --> 00:03:09.574
places where robots
still have difficulties

00:03:09.598 --> 00:03:11.654
and where animals
can do a much better job.

00:03:11.678 --> 00:03:14.174
The robot can be a wonderful
scientific tool as well.

00:03:14.198 --> 00:03:16.818
There are some very nice projects
where robots are used,

00:03:16.842 --> 00:03:20.814
like a scientific tool for neuroscience,
for biomechanics or for hydrodynamics.

00:03:20.838 --> 00:03:22.958
And this is exactly
the purpose of Pleurobot.

00:03:23.558 --> 00:03:26.494
So what we do in my lab
is to collaborate with neurobiologists

00:03:26.518 --> 00:03:29.734
like Jean-Marie Cabelguen,
a neurobiologist in Bordeaux in France,

00:03:29.758 --> 00:03:33.798
and we want to make spinal cord models
and validate them on robots.

00:03:34.438 --> 00:03:36.054
And here we want to start simple.

00:03:36.078 --> 00:03:38.054
So it's good to start with simple animals

00:03:38.078 --> 00:03:40.334
like lampreys, which are
very primitive fish,

00:03:40.358 --> 00:03:42.854
and then gradually
go toward more complex locomotion,

00:03:42.878 --> 00:03:44.134
like in salamanders,

00:03:44.158 --> 00:03:45.654
but also in cats and in humans,

00:03:45.678 --> 00:03:46.878
in mammals.

00:03:47.838 --> 00:03:50.214
And here, a robot becomes
an interesting tool

00:03:50.238 --> 00:03:52.174
to validate our models.

00:03:52.198 --> 00:03:55.214
And in fact, for me, Pleurobot
is a kind of dream becoming true.

00:03:55.238 --> 00:03:58.494
Like, more or less 20 years ago
I was already working on a computer

00:03:58.518 --> 00:04:01.174
making simulations of lamprey
and salamander locomotion

00:04:01.198 --> 00:04:02.734
during my PhD.

00:04:02.758 --> 00:04:06.134
But I always knew that my simulations
were just approximations.

00:04:06.158 --> 00:04:10.134
Like, simulating the physics in water
or with mud or with complex ground,

00:04:10.158 --> 00:04:12.814
it's very hard to simulate that
properly on a computer.

00:04:12.838 --> 00:04:14.878
Why not have a real robot
and real physics?

00:04:15.558 --> 00:04:18.694
So among all these animals,
one of my favorites is the salamander.

00:04:18.718 --> 00:04:22.174
You might ask why,
and it's because as an amphibian,

00:04:22.198 --> 00:04:25.054
it's a really key animal
from an evolutionary point of view.

00:04:25.078 --> 00:04:27.134
It makes a wonderful link
between swimming,

00:04:27.158 --> 00:04:29.054
as you find it in eels or fish,

00:04:29.078 --> 00:04:33.198
and quadruped locomotion,
as you see in mammals, in cats and humans.

00:04:34.118 --> 00:04:35.774
And in fact, the modern salamander

00:04:35.798 --> 00:04:38.174
is very close to the first
terrestrial vertebrate,

00:04:38.198 --> 00:04:39.734
so it's almost a living fossil,

00:04:39.758 --> 00:04:41.694
which gives us access to our ancestor,

00:04:41.718 --> 00:04:44.638
the ancestor to all terrestrial tetrapods.

00:04:45.198 --> 00:04:46.574
So the salamander swims

00:04:46.598 --> 00:04:49.094
by doing what's called
an anguilliform swimming gait,

00:04:49.118 --> 00:04:52.758
so they propagate a nice traveling wave
of muscle activity from head to tail.

00:04:53.398 --> 00:04:55.574
And if you place
the salamander on the ground,

00:04:55.598 --> 00:04:57.934
it switches to what's called
a walking trot gait.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.821
In this case, you have nice
periodic activation of the limbs

00:05:00.845 --> 00:05:02.454
which are very nicely coordinated

00:05:02.478 --> 00:05:05.134
with this standing wave
undulation of the body,

00:05:05.158 --> 00:05:08.814
and that's exactly the gait
that you are seeing here on Pleurobot.

00:05:08.838 --> 00:05:11.814
Now, one thing which is very surprising
and fascinating in fact

00:05:11.838 --> 00:05:15.974
is the fact that all this can be generated
just by the spinal cord and the body.

00:05:15.998 --> 00:05:17.998
So if you take
a decerebrated salamander --

00:05:18.022 --> 00:05:20.038
it's not so nice
but you remove the head --

00:05:20.062 --> 00:05:22.734
and if you electrically
stimulate the spinal cord,

00:05:22.758 --> 00:05:26.014
at low level of stimulation
this will induce a walking-like gait.

00:05:26.038 --> 00:05:28.494
If you stimulate a bit more,
the gait accelerates.

00:05:28.518 --> 00:05:30.414
And at some point, there's a threshold,

00:05:30.438 --> 00:05:32.974
and automatically,
the animal switches to swimming.

00:05:32.998 --> 00:05:34.374
This is amazing.

00:05:34.398 --> 00:05:35.894
Just changing the global drive,

00:05:35.918 --> 00:05:37.654
as if you are pressing the gas pedal

00:05:37.678 --> 00:05:39.814
of descending modulation
to your spinal cord,

00:05:39.838 --> 00:05:42.838
makes a complete switch
between two very different gaits.

00:05:44.398 --> 00:05:46.974
And in fact, the same
has been observed in cats.

00:05:46.998 --> 00:05:49.014
If you stimulate the spinal cord of a cat,

00:05:49.038 --> 00:05:51.254
you can switch between
walk, trot and gallop.

00:05:51.278 --> 00:05:54.014
Or in birds, you can make a bird
switch between walking,

00:05:54.038 --> 00:05:55.494
at a low level of stimulation,

00:05:55.518 --> 00:05:58.334
and flapping its wings
at high-level stimulation.

00:05:58.358 --> 00:06:00.374
And this really shows that the spinal cord

00:06:00.398 --> 00:06:02.814
is a very sophisticated
locomotion controller.

00:06:02.838 --> 00:06:05.294
So we studied salamander locomotion
in more detail,

00:06:05.318 --> 00:06:08.414
and we had in fact access
to a very nice X-ray video machine

00:06:08.438 --> 00:06:12.014
from Professor Martin Fischer
in Jena University in Germany.

00:06:12.038 --> 00:06:14.614
And thanks to that,
you really have an amazing machine

00:06:14.638 --> 00:06:17.094
to record all the bone motion
in great detail.

00:06:17.118 --> 00:06:18.374
That's what we did.

00:06:18.398 --> 00:06:21.574
So we basically figured out
which bones are important for us

00:06:21.598 --> 00:06:24.614
and collected their motion in 3D.

00:06:24.638 --> 00:06:27.334
And what we did is collect
a whole database of motions,

00:06:27.358 --> 00:06:29.014
both on ground and in water,

00:06:29.038 --> 00:06:31.522
to really collect a whole database
of motor behaviors

00:06:31.547 --> 00:06:32.791
that a real animal can do.

00:06:32.816 --> 00:06:35.966
And then our job as roboticists
was to replicate that in our robot.

00:06:35.991 --> 00:06:39.374
So we did a whole optimization process
to find out the right structure,

00:06:39.398 --> 00:06:42.054
where to place the motors,
how to connect them together,

00:06:42.078 --> 00:06:44.958
to be able to replay
these motions as well as possible.

00:06:45.638 --> 00:06:47.998
And this is how Pleurobot came to life.

00:06:49.158 --> 00:06:51.574
So let's look at how close
it is to the real animal.

00:06:52.918 --> 00:06:55.414
So what you see here
is almost a direct comparison

00:06:55.438 --> 00:06:58.134
between the walking
of the real animal and the Pleurobot.

00:06:58.158 --> 00:07:00.894
You can see that we have
almost a one-to-one exact replay

00:07:00.918 --> 00:07:02.174
of the walking gait.

00:07:02.198 --> 00:07:04.798
If you go backwards and slowly,
you see it even better.

00:07:07.478 --> 00:07:09.854
But even better, we can do swimming.

00:07:09.878 --> 00:07:12.894
So for that we have a dry suit
that we put all over the robot --

00:07:12.918 --> 00:07:14.014
(Laughter)

00:07:14.038 --> 00:07:17.214
and then we can go in water
and start replaying the swimming gaits.

00:07:17.238 --> 00:07:20.574
And here, we were very happy,
because this is difficult to do.

00:07:20.598 --> 00:07:22.814
The physics of interaction are complex.

00:07:22.838 --> 00:07:25.254
Our robot is much bigger
than a small animal,

00:07:25.278 --> 00:07:28.334
so we had to do what's called
dynamic scaling of the frequencies

00:07:28.358 --> 00:07:30.694
to make sure we had
the same interaction physics.

00:07:30.718 --> 00:07:33.134
But you see at the end,
we have a very close match,

00:07:33.158 --> 00:07:35.038
and we were very, very happy with this.

00:07:35.438 --> 00:07:37.654
So let's go to the spinal cord.

00:07:37.678 --> 00:07:39.974
So here what we did
with Jean-Marie Cabelguen

00:07:39.998 --> 00:07:42.238
is model the spinal cord circuits.

00:07:42.998 --> 00:07:45.134
And what's interesting
is that the salamander

00:07:45.158 --> 00:07:46.778
has kept a very primitive circuit,

00:07:46.802 --> 00:07:49.454
which is very similar
to the one we find in the lamprey,

00:07:49.478 --> 00:07:51.454
this primitive eel-like fish,

00:07:51.478 --> 00:07:53.214
and it looks like during evolution,

00:07:53.238 --> 00:07:56.174
new neural oscillators
have been added to control the limbs,

00:07:56.198 --> 00:07:57.614
to do the leg locomotion.

00:07:57.638 --> 00:07:59.814
And we know where
these neural oscillators are

00:07:59.838 --> 00:08:02.094
but what we did was to make
a mathematical model

00:08:02.118 --> 00:08:03.734
to see how they should be coupled

00:08:03.758 --> 00:08:06.694
to allow this transition
between the two very different gaits.

00:08:06.718 --> 00:08:09.278
And we tested that on board of a robot.

00:08:09.638 --> 00:08:10.838
And this is how it looks.

00:08:18.878 --> 00:08:21.894
So what you see here
is a previous version of Pleurobot

00:08:21.918 --> 00:08:25.014
that's completely controlled
by our spinal cord model

00:08:25.038 --> 00:08:26.638
programmed on board of the robot.

00:08:27.238 --> 00:08:28.454
And the only thing we do

00:08:28.478 --> 00:08:30.654
is send to the robot
through a remote control

00:08:30.678 --> 00:08:33.174
the two descending signals
it normally should receive

00:08:33.198 --> 00:08:34.798
from the upper part of the brain.

00:08:35.438 --> 00:08:38.134
And what's interesting is,
by playing with these signals,

00:08:38.158 --> 00:08:40.958
we can completely control
speed, heading and type of gait.

00:08:41.558 --> 00:08:42.774
For instance,

00:08:42.798 --> 00:08:46.374
when we stimulate at a low level,
we have the walking gait,

00:08:46.398 --> 00:08:48.374
and at some point, if we stimulate a lot,

00:08:48.398 --> 00:08:50.558
very rapidly it switches
to the swimming gait.

00:08:51.438 --> 00:08:53.654
And finally, we can also
do turning very nicely

00:08:53.678 --> 00:08:57.198
by just stimulating more one side
of the spinal cord than the other.

00:08:58.158 --> 00:08:59.774
And I think it's really beautiful

00:08:59.798 --> 00:09:02.054
how nature has distributed control

00:09:02.078 --> 00:09:04.934
to really give a lot of responsibility
to the spinal cord

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.614
so that the upper part of the brain
doesn't need to worry about every muscle.

00:09:08.638 --> 00:09:11.174
It just has to worry
about this high-level modulation,

00:09:11.198 --> 00:09:14.774
and it's really the job of the spinal cord
to coordinate all the muscles.

00:09:14.798 --> 00:09:18.318
So now let's go to cat locomotion
and the importance of biomechanics.

00:09:19.038 --> 00:09:20.294
So this is another project

00:09:20.318 --> 00:09:22.734
where we studied cat biomechanics,

00:09:22.758 --> 00:09:26.654
and we wanted to see how much
the morphology helps locomotion.

00:09:26.678 --> 00:09:30.294
And we found three important
criteria in the properties,

00:09:30.318 --> 00:09:31.638
basically, of the limbs.

00:09:32.278 --> 00:09:34.254
The first one is that a cat limb

00:09:34.278 --> 00:09:36.974
more or less looks
like a pantograph-like structure.

00:09:36.998 --> 00:09:39.214
So a pantograph is a mechanical structure

00:09:39.238 --> 00:09:42.638
which keeps the upper segment
and the lower segments always parallel.

00:09:43.558 --> 00:09:46.654
So a simple geometrical system
that kind of coordinates a bit

00:09:46.678 --> 00:09:48.494
the internal movement of the segments.

00:09:48.518 --> 00:09:51.574
A second property of cat limbs
is that they are very lightweight.

00:09:51.598 --> 00:09:53.454
Most of the muscles are in the trunk,

00:09:53.478 --> 00:09:56.374
which is a good idea,
because then the limbs have low inertia

00:09:56.398 --> 00:09:58.174
and can be moved very rapidly.

00:09:58.198 --> 00:10:02.014
The last final important property is this
very elastic behavior of the cat limb,

00:10:02.038 --> 00:10:04.694
so to handle impacts and forces.

00:10:04.718 --> 00:10:07.054
And this is how we designed Cheetah-Cub.

00:10:07.078 --> 00:10:09.278
So let's invite Cheetah-Cub onstage.

00:10:14.118 --> 00:10:17.774
So this is Peter Eckert,
who does his PhD on this robot,

00:10:17.798 --> 00:10:19.854
and as you see, it's a cute little robot.

00:10:19.878 --> 00:10:21.134
It looks a bit like a toy,

00:10:21.158 --> 00:10:23.214
but it was really used
as a scientific tool

00:10:23.238 --> 00:10:26.534
to investigate these properties
of the legs of the cat.

00:10:26.558 --> 00:10:29.174
So you see, it's very compliant,
very lightweight,

00:10:29.198 --> 00:10:30.454
and also very elastic,

00:10:30.478 --> 00:10:33.254
so you can easily press it down
and it will not break.

00:10:33.278 --> 00:10:34.734
It will just jump, in fact.

00:10:34.758 --> 00:10:37.638
And this very elastic property
is also very important.

00:10:39.118 --> 00:10:41.014
And you also see a bit these properties

00:10:41.038 --> 00:10:43.438
of these three segments
of the leg as pantograph.

00:10:44.238 --> 00:10:47.014
Now, what's interesting
is that this quite dynamic gait

00:10:47.038 --> 00:10:48.934
is obtained purely in open loop,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.094
meaning no sensors,
no complex feedback loops.

00:10:52.118 --> 00:10:54.534
And that's interesting, because it means

00:10:54.558 --> 00:10:58.574
that just the mechanics
already stabilized this quite rapid gait,

00:10:58.598 --> 00:11:02.774
and that really good mechanics
already basically simplify locomotion.

00:11:02.798 --> 00:11:06.094
To the extent that we can even
disturb a bit locomotion,

00:11:06.118 --> 00:11:07.774
as you will see in the next video,

00:11:07.798 --> 00:11:11.694
where we can for instance do some exercise
where we have the robot go down a step,

00:11:11.718 --> 00:11:13.334
and the robot will not fall over,

00:11:13.358 --> 00:11:14.934
which was a surprise for us.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.374
This is a small perturbation.

00:11:16.398 --> 00:11:18.814
I was expecting the robot
to immediately fall over,

00:11:18.838 --> 00:11:21.274
because there are no sensors,
no fast feedback loop.

00:11:21.298 --> 00:11:23.494
But no, just the mechanics
stabilized the gait,

00:11:23.518 --> 00:11:25.094
and the robot doesn't fall over.

00:11:25.118 --> 00:11:28.254
Obviously, if you make the step bigger,
and if you have obstacles,

00:11:28.278 --> 00:11:31.934
you need the full control loops
and reflexes and everything.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.894
But what's important here
is that just for small perturbation,

00:11:34.918 --> 00:11:36.414
the mechanics are right.

00:11:36.438 --> 00:11:38.534
And I think this is
a very important message

00:11:38.558 --> 00:11:40.749
from biomechanics and robotics
to neuroscience,

00:11:40.773 --> 00:11:45.453
saying don't underestimate to what extent
the body already helps locomotion.

00:11:47.398 --> 00:11:49.558
Now, how does this relate
to human locomotion?

00:11:49.918 --> 00:11:53.558
Clearly, human locomotion is more complex
than cat and salamander locomotion,

00:11:54.318 --> 00:11:57.454
but at the same time, the nervous system
of humans is very similar

00:11:57.478 --> 00:11:59.054
to that of other vertebrates.

00:11:59.078 --> 00:12:00.534
And especially the spinal cord

00:12:00.558 --> 00:12:03.198
is also the key controller
for locomotion in humans.

00:12:03.718 --> 00:12:06.134
That's why, if there's a lesion
of the spinal cord,

00:12:06.158 --> 00:12:07.654
this has dramatic effects.

00:12:07.678 --> 00:12:10.454
The person can become
paraplegic or tetraplegic.

00:12:10.478 --> 00:12:12.854
This is because the brain
loses this communication

00:12:12.878 --> 00:12:14.134
with the spinal cord.

00:12:14.158 --> 00:12:16.374
Especially, it loses
this descending modulation

00:12:16.398 --> 00:12:18.318
to initiate and modulate locomotion.

00:12:19.598 --> 00:12:21.294
So a big goal of neuroprosthetics

00:12:21.318 --> 00:12:23.694
is to be able to reactivate
that communication

00:12:23.718 --> 00:12:26.158
using electrical or chemical stimulations.

00:12:26.798 --> 00:12:29.734
And there are several teams
in the world that do exactly that,

00:12:29.758 --> 00:12:30.974
especially at EPFL.

00:12:30.998 --> 00:12:33.494
My colleagues Grégoire Courtine
and Silvestro Micera,

00:12:33.518 --> 00:12:34.758
with whom I collaborate.

00:12:35.918 --> 00:12:39.014
But to do this properly,
it's very important to understand

00:12:39.038 --> 00:12:40.774
how the spinal cord works,

00:12:40.798 --> 00:12:42.494
how it interacts with the body,

00:12:42.518 --> 00:12:44.998
and how the brain
communicates with the spinal cord.

00:12:45.758 --> 00:12:48.654
This is where the robots
and models that I've presented today

00:12:48.678 --> 00:12:50.574
will hopefully play a key role

00:12:50.598 --> 00:12:53.254
towards these very important goals.

00:12:53.278 --> 00:12:54.494
Thank you.

00:12:54.518 --> 00:12:59.078
(Applause)

00:13:04.058 --> 00:13:06.694
Bruno Giussani: Auke, I've seen
in your lab other robots

00:13:06.718 --> 00:13:09.174
that do things like swim in pollution

00:13:09.198 --> 00:13:11.654
and measure the pollution while they swim.

00:13:11.678 --> 00:13:12.894
But for this one,

00:13:12.918 --> 00:13:16.398
you mentioned in your talk,
like a side project,

00:13:17.598 --> 00:13:18.814
search and rescue,

00:13:18.838 --> 00:13:21.014
and it does have a camera on its nose.

00:13:21.038 --> 00:13:23.534
Auke Ijspeert: Absolutely. So the robot --

00:13:23.558 --> 00:13:24.987
We have some spin-off projects

00:13:25.011 --> 00:13:28.454
where we would like to use the robots
to do search and rescue inspection,

00:13:28.478 --> 00:13:30.054
so this robot is now seeing you.

00:13:30.078 --> 00:13:33.254
And the big dream is to,
if you have a difficult situation

00:13:33.278 --> 00:13:36.894
like a collapsed building
or a building that is flooded,

00:13:36.918 --> 00:13:40.254
and this is very dangerous
for a rescue team or even rescue dogs,

00:13:40.278 --> 00:13:43.174
why not send in a robot
that can crawl around, swim, walk,

00:13:43.198 --> 00:13:46.374
with a camera onboard
to do inspection and identify survivors

00:13:46.398 --> 00:13:49.174
and possibly create
a communication link with the survivor.

00:13:49.198 --> 00:13:52.774
BG: Of course, assuming the survivors
don't get scared by the shape of this.

00:13:52.798 --> 00:13:56.094
AI: Yeah, we should probably
change the appearance quite a bit,

00:13:56.118 --> 00:13:58.934
because here I guess a survivor
might die of a heart attack

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.494
just of being worried
that this would feed on you.

00:14:01.518 --> 00:14:04.374
But by changing the appearance
and it making it more robust,

00:14:04.398 --> 00:14:06.454
I'm sure we can make
a good tool out of it.

00:14:06.478 --> 00:14:08.764
BG: Thank you very much.
Thank you and your team.

title: Our campaign to ban plastic bags in Bali
transcript: Melati Wijsen: Bali — island of gods.Isabel Wijsen: A green paradise.MW: Or ... a paradise lost. Bali: island of garbage.IW: In Bali, we generate 680 cubic meters of plastic garbage a day. That's about a 14-story building. And when it comes to plastic bags, less than five percent gets recycled.MW: We know that changes the image you may have of our island. It changed ours, too, when we learned about it, when we learned that almost all plastic bags in Bali end up in our drains and then in our rivers and then in our ocean. And those that don't even make it to the ocean, they're either burned or littered.IW: So we decided to do something about it. And we've been working for almost three years now to try to say no to plastic bags on our home island. And we have had some significant successes.MW: We are sisters, and we go to the best school on earth: Green School, Bali. Green School is not only different in the way that it is built out of bamboo, but also in the way that it teaches. We are taught to become leaders of today, something a normal textbook cannot match.IW: One day we had a lesson in class where we learned about significant people, like Nelson Mandela, Lady Diana and Mahatma Gandhi. Walking home that day, we agreed that we also wanted to be significant. Why should we wait until we were grown up to be significant? We wanted to do something now.MW: Sitting on the sofa that night, we brainstormed and thought of all the issues facing Bali. And one thing that stood out to us the most was the plastic garbage. But that is a huge problem. So we looked into what was a realistic target for us kids: plastic bags. And the idea was born.IW: We started researching, and let's just say, the more we learned, there was nothing good about plastic bags. And you know what? We don't even need them.MW: We were really inspired by the efforts to say no to plastic bags in many other places, from Hawaii to Rwanda and to severals cities like Oakland and Dublin.IW: And so the idea turned into the launch of "Bye Bye Plastic Bags." MW: In the years that we have been campaigning, we have learned a lot.Lesson number one: you cannot do it all by yourself. You need a big team of like-minded kids, and so we formed the Bye Bye Plastic Bags crew. The volunteer team includes children from all over the island, from both international and local schools. And together with them, we started a multi-layered approach, based on an on- and off-line signature petition, educational and inspirational presentations at schools and we raise general awareness at markets, festivals, beach clean-ups. And last but not least, we distribute alternative bags, bags like net bags, recycled newspaper bags or 100 percent organic material bags, all made by local initiatives on the island.IW: We run a pilot village, home of 800 families. The village mayor was our first friend and he loved our T-shirts, so that helped. We focused on making the customers aware, because that's where the change needs to happen. The village is already two-thirds along the way of becoming plastic bag free.Our first attempts to get the government of Bali on board failed. So we thought, "Hmm ... a petition with one million signatures. They can't ignore us, right?"MW: Right!IW: But, who would have guessed one million signatures is, like, a thousand times a thousand?(Laughter)We got stuck — till we learned lesson number two: think outside the box. Someone mentioned that the Bali airport handles 16 million arrivals and departures a year.MW: But how do we get into the airport? And here comes lesson number three: persistence. Off we headed to the airport. We got past the janitor. And then it was his boss's boss, and then the assistant office manager, and then the office manager, and then ... we got shuffled down two levels and thought, well, here comes the janitor again.And after several days knocking on doors and just being kids on a mission, we finally got to the commercial manager of Bali airports. And we gave him the "Bali of plastic bags" speech, and being a very nice man, he said, [imitating the man's voice] "I cannot believe what I'm about say, but I'm going to give authorization to collect signatures behind customs and immigrations."(Laughter)(Applause)IW: In our first hour and a half there, we got almost 1,000 signatures. How cool is that?Lesson number four: you need champions at all levels of society, from students to commercial managers to famous people. And thanks to the attraction of Green School, we had access to a steady stream of celebrities. Ban Ki Moon taught us that Secretary-Generals of the United Nations don't sign petitions —(Laughter)even if kids ask nicely. But he promised to spread the word, and now we work closely with the United Nations.MW: Jane Goodall taught us the power of a people's network. She started with just one Roots & Shoots group and now she has 4,000 groups around the world. We are one of them. She's a real inspiration.If you're a fellow Rotarian, nice to meet you. We're Interactors, the youngest department of Rotary International.IW: But we have also learned much about patience,MW: how to deal with frustrations,IW: leadership,MW: teamwork,IW: friendship,MW: we learned more about the Balinese and their cultureIW: and we learned about the importance of commitment.MW: It's not always easy. Sometimes it does get a little bit hard to walk your talk.IW: But last year, we did exactly that. We went to India to give a talk, and our parents took us to visit the former private house of Mahatma Gandhi. We learned about the power of hunger strikes he did to reach his goals. Yes, by the end of the tour, when we met our parents again, we both made a decision and said, "We're going on a hunger strike!"(Laughter)MW: And you can probably imagine their faces. It took a lot of convincing, and not only to our parents but to our friends and to our teachers as well. Isabel and I were serious about doing this. So we met with a nutritionist, and we came up with a compromise of not eating from sunrise to sunset every day until the governor of Bali would agree to meet with us to talk about how to stop plastic bags on Bali.IW: Our "mogak makan," as it is called in Bahasa Indonesia, started. We used social media to support our goal and already on day two, police started to come to our home and school. What were these two girls doing? We knew we weren't making the governor look his best by doing this food strike — we could have gone to jail. But, hey, it worked. Twenty-four hours later, we were picked up from school and escorted to the office of the governor.MW: And there he was —(Applause)waiting for us to meet and speak, being all supportive and thankful for our willingness to care for the beauty and the environment of Bali.He signed a promise to help the people of Bali say no to plastic bags. And we are now friends, and on a regular basis, we remind him and his team of the promises he has made. And indeed, recently he stated and committed that Bali will be plastic bag free by 2018.(Applause)IW: Also, at the International Airport of Bali, one of our supporters is planning to start a plastic bag-free policy by 2016.MW: Stop handing out free plastic bags and bring in your own reusable bag is our next message to change that mindset of the public.IW: Our short-term campaign, "One Island / One Voice," is all about this. We check and recognize the shops and restaurants that have declared themselves a plastic bag-free zone, and we put this sticker at their entrance and publish their names on social media and some important magazines on Bali. And conversely, that highlights those who do not have the sticker.(Laughter)MW: So, why are we actually telling you all of this? Well, partly, it is because we are proud of the results that, together with our team, we have been able to reach. But also because along the way, we have learned that kids can do things. We can make things happen. Isabel and I were only 10 and 12 years old when we started this. We never had a business plan, nor a fixed strategy, nor any hidden agendas — just the idea in front of us and a group of friends working with us. All we wanted to do was stop those plastic bags from wrapping and suffocating our beautiful home. Kids have a boundless energy and a motivation to be the change the world needs.IW: So to all the kids of this beautiful but challenging world: go for it! Make that difference. We're not telling you it's going to be easy. We're telling you it's going to be worth it. Us kids may only be 25 percent of the world's population, but we are 100 percent of the future.MW: We still have a lot of work to do, but know that we still not stop until the first question asked when arriving at the Bali airports will beBoth: "Welcome to Bali, do you have nay plastic bags to declare?"(Laughter)Om shanti shanti shanti om.Thank you.(Applause)
