And last but not least,

00:03:27.876 --> 00:03:29.922
we distribute alternative bags,

00:03:29.946 --> 00:03:31.670
bags like net bags,

00:03:31.694 --> 00:03:33.016
recycled newspaper bags

00:03:33.040 --> 00:03:35.760
or 100 percent organic material bags,

00:03:35.784 --> 00:03:38.297
all made by local
initiatives on the island.

00:03:38.856 --> 00:03:40.250
IW: We run a pilot village,

00:03:40.274 --> 00:03:42.386
home of 800 families.

00:03:42.910 --> 00:03:44.733
The village mayor was our first friend

00:03:44.757 --> 00:03:47.223
and he loved our T-shirts, so that helped.

00:03:48.035 --> 00:03:50.703
We focused on making the customers aware,

00:03:50.727 --> 00:03:53.445
because that's where the change
needs to happen.

00:03:54.224 --> 00:03:56.421
The village is already
two-thirds along the way

00:03:56.445 --> 00:03:58.450
of becoming plastic bag free.

00:03:59.288 --> 00:04:04.163
Our first attempts to get the government
of Bali on board failed.

00:04:04.654 --> 00:04:05.804
So we thought,

00:04:06.349 --> 00:04:10.649
"Hmm ... a petition
with one million signatures.

00:04:10.673 --> 00:04:12.666
They can't ignore us, right?"

00:04:12.690 --> 00:04:13.853
MW: Right!

00:04:14.216 --> 00:04:16.051
IW: But, who would have guessed

00:04:16.075 --> 00:04:20.237
one million signatures is, like,
a thousand times a thousand?

00:04:20.261 --> 00:04:21.888
(Laughter)

00:04:22.228 --> 00:04:23.793
We got stuck --

00:04:24.705 --> 00:04:26.696
till we learned lesson number two:

00:04:27.465 --> 00:04:29.420
think outside the box.

00:04:29.766 --> 00:04:30.917
Someone mentioned

00:04:30.941 --> 00:04:37.342
that the Bali airport handles
16 million arrivals and departures a year.

00:04:38.252 --> 00:04:41.568
MW: But how do we get into the airport?

00:04:41.951 --> 00:04:43.644
And here comes lesson number three:

00:04:44.194 --> 00:04:45.634
persistence.

00:04:46.099 --> 00:04:47.726
Off we headed to the airport.

00:04:47.750 --> 00:04:49.402
We got past the janitor.

00:04:49.777 --> 00:04:51.663
And then it was his boss's boss,

00:04:51.687 --> 00:04:53.948
and then the assistant office manager,

00:04:53.972 --> 00:04:55.357
and then the office manager,

00:04:55.381 --> 00:04:56.552
and then ...

00:04:56.576 --> 00:04:58.723
we got shuffled down
two levels and thought,

00:04:58.747 --> 00:05:00.912
well, here comes the janitor again.

00:05:01.495 --> 00:05:03.543
And after several days knocking on doors

00:05:03.567 --> 00:05:05.883
and just being kids on a mission,

00:05:05.907 --> 00:05:09.795
we finally got to the commercial
manager of Bali airports.

00:05:10.326 --> 00:05:14.239
And we gave him the "Bali of plastic bags"
speech, and being a very nice man,

00:05:14.263 --> 00:05:17.961
he said, [imitating the man's voice]
"I cannot believe what I'm about say,

00:05:17.985 --> 00:05:20.228
but I'm going to give authorization

00:05:20.252 --> 00:05:23.209
to collect signatures
behind customs and immigrations."

00:05:23.233 --> 00:05:24.577
(Laughter)

00:05:24.601 --> 00:05:28.896
(Applause)

00:05:28.920 --> 00:05:30.864
IW: In our first hour and a half there,

00:05:30.888 --> 00:05:33.563
we got almost 1,000 signatures.

00:05:33.912 --> 00:05:35.213
How cool is that?

00:05:36.298 --> 00:05:37.809
Lesson number four:

00:05:37.833 --> 00:05:40.834
you need champions
at all levels of society,

00:05:41.444 --> 00:05:45.253
from students to commercial
managers to famous people.

00:05:46.055 --> 00:05:48.167
And thanks to the attraction
of Green School,

00:05:48.191 --> 00:05:50.857
we had access to a steady
stream of celebrities.

00:05:51.895 --> 00:05:53.094
Ban Ki Moon taught us

00:05:53.118 --> 00:05:56.479
that Secretary-Generals
of the United Nations

00:05:56.503 --> 00:05:58.154
don't sign petitions --

00:05:58.178 --> 00:05:59.179
(Laughter)

00:05:59.203 --> 00:06:01.040
even if kids ask nicely.

00:06:01.064 --> 00:06:02.749
But he promised to spread the word,

00:06:02.773 --> 00:06:05.286
and now we work closely
with the United Nations.

00:06:05.659 --> 00:06:08.602
MW: Jane Goodall taught us
the power of a people's network.

00:06:09.013 --> 00:06:12.053
She started with just one
Roots & Shoots group

00:06:12.077 --> 00:06:15.368
and now she has 4,000 groups
around the world.

00:06:15.392 --> 00:06:16.565
We are one of them.

00:06:16.589 --> 00:06:18.031
She's a real inspiration.

00:06:18.689 --> 00:06:20.441
If you're a fellow Rotarian,

00:06:20.465 --> 00:06:21.755
nice to meet you.

00:06:21.779 --> 00:06:22.930
We're Interactors,

00:06:22.954 --> 00:06:25.285
the youngest department
of Rotary International.

00:06:26.531 --> 00:06:29.774
IW: But we have also learned
much about patience,

00:06:29.798 --> 00:06:32.055
MW: how to deal with frustrations,

00:06:32.079 --> 00:06:33.230
IW: leadership,

00:06:33.254 --> 00:06:34.423
MW: teamwork,

00:06:34.447 --> 00:06:35.598
IW: friendship,

00:06:35.622 --> 00:06:38.281
MW: we learned more
about the Balinese and their culture

00:06:38.305 --> 00:06:41.463
IW: and we learned
about the importance of commitment.

00:06:42.064 --> 00:06:43.798
MW: It's not always easy.

00:06:43.822 --> 00:06:47.287
Sometimes it does get
a little bit hard to walk your talk.

00:06:47.788 --> 00:06:50.215
IW: But last year, we did exactly that.

00:06:50.621 --> 00:06:52.224
We went to India to give a talk,

00:06:52.248 --> 00:06:53.803
and our parents took us to visit

00:06:53.827 --> 00:06:56.415
the former private house
of Mahatma Gandhi.

00:06:57.174 --> 00:06:59.428
We learned about the power
of hunger strikes

00:06:59.452 --> 00:07:00.728
he did to reach his goals.

00:07:01.287 --> 00:07:03.285
Yes, by the end of the tour,

00:07:03.309 --> 00:07:04.960
when we met our parents again,

00:07:04.984 --> 00:07:06.650
we both made a decision and said,

00:07:06.674 --> 00:07:08.430
"We're going on a hunger strike!"

00:07:08.454 --> 00:07:09.455
(Laughter)

00:07:09.479 --> 00:07:12.378
MW: And you can probably
imagine their faces.

00:07:12.402 --> 00:07:14.680
It took a lot of convincing,

00:07:14.704 --> 00:07:16.436
and not only to our parents

00:07:16.460 --> 00:07:18.752
but to our friends
and to our teachers as well.

00:07:19.519 --> 00:07:22.490
Isabel and I were serious
about doing this.

00:07:22.514 --> 00:07:24.123
So we met with a nutritionist,

00:07:24.147 --> 00:07:25.987
and we came up with a compromise

00:07:26.011 --> 00:07:30.276
of not eating from sunrise
to sunset every day

00:07:30.300 --> 00:07:32.905
until the governor of Bali
would agree to meet with us

00:07:32.929 --> 00:07:36.416
to talk about how to stop
plastic bags on Bali.

00:07:37.076 --> 00:07:41.096
IW: Our "mogak makan,"
as it is called in Bahasa Indonesia,

00:07:41.120 --> 00:07:42.271
started.

00:07:42.295 --> 00:07:44.284
We used social media to support our goal

00:07:44.308 --> 00:07:46.075
and already on day two,

00:07:46.099 --> 00:07:48.365
police started to come
to our home and school.

00:07:48.682 --> 00:07:50.879
What were these two girls doing?

00:07:51.424 --> 00:07:53.934
We knew we weren't making
the governor look his best

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.839
by doing this food strike --

00:07:55.863 --> 00:07:57.297
we could have gone to jail.

00:07:57.726 --> 00:07:59.655
But, hey, it worked.

00:07:59.679 --> 00:08:00.905
Twenty-four hours later,

00:08:00.929 --> 00:08:02.341
we were picked up from school

00:08:02.365 --> 00:08:04.388
and escorted to the office
of the governor.

00:08:05.241 --> 00:08:06.754
MW: And there he was --

00:08:06.778 --> 00:08:08.987
(Applause)

00:08:09.011 --> 00:08:10.941
waiting for us to meet and speak,

00:08:10.965 --> 00:08:13.515
being all supportive
and thankful for our willingness

00:08:13.539 --> 00:08:16.151
to care for the beauty
and the environment of Bali.

00:08:16.770 --> 00:08:17.921
He signed a promise

00:08:17.945 --> 00:08:20.696
to help the people of Bali
say no to plastic bags.

00:08:20.720 --> 00:08:21.874
And we are now friends,

00:08:21.898 --> 00:08:23.294
and on a regular basis,

00:08:23.318 --> 00:08:26.615
we remind him and his team
of the promises he has made.

00:08:27.330 --> 00:08:28.481
And indeed,

00:08:28.505 --> 00:08:30.411
recently he stated and committed

00:08:30.435 --> 00:08:35.078
that Bali will be
plastic bag free by 2018.

00:08:35.102 --> 00:08:41.938
(Applause)

00:08:43.456 --> 00:08:48.073
IW: Also, at the International Airport
of Bali, one of our supporters

00:08:48.097 --> 00:08:52.659
is planning to start
a plastic bag-free policy by 2016.

00:08:53.144 --> 00:08:55.131
MW: Stop handing out free plastic bags

00:08:55.155 --> 00:08:56.851
and bring in your own reusable bag

00:08:56.875 --> 00:09:00.319
is our next message to change
that mindset of the public.

00:09:01.363 --> 00:09:03.060
IW: Our short-term campaign,

00:09:03.084 --> 00:09:04.516
"One Island / One Voice,"

00:09:04.540 --> 00:09:05.974
is all about this.

00:09:05.998 --> 00:09:08.677
We check and recognize
the shops and restaurants

00:09:08.701 --> 00:09:11.544
that have declared themselves
a plastic bag-free zone,

00:09:11.568 --> 00:09:13.941
and we put this sticker at their entrance

00:09:13.965 --> 00:09:16.283
and publish their names on social media

00:09:16.307 --> 00:09:18.383
and some important magazines on Bali.

00:09:18.787 --> 00:09:19.938
And conversely,

00:09:19.962 --> 00:09:22.787
that highlights those
who do not have the sticker.

00:09:22.811 --> 00:09:24.198
(Laughter)

00:09:24.689 --> 00:09:28.008
MW: So, why are we actually
telling you all of this?

00:09:28.631 --> 00:09:30.549
Well, partly, it is because we are proud

00:09:30.573 --> 00:09:32.644
of the results that,
together with our team,

00:09:32.668 --> 00:09:34.024
we have been able to reach.

00:09:34.427 --> 00:09:36.515
But also because along the way,

00:09:36.539 --> 00:09:39.379
we have learned that kids can do things.

00:09:39.403 --> 00:09:41.057
We can make things happen.

00:09:41.849 --> 00:09:44.276
Isabel and I were only 10 and 12 years old

00:09:44.300 --> 00:09:45.859
when we started this.

00:09:45.883 --> 00:09:47.936
We never had a business plan,

00:09:47.960 --> 00:09:49.184
nor a fixed strategy,

00:09:49.208 --> 00:09:51.127
nor any hidden agendas --

00:09:51.151 --> 00:09:53.591
just the idea in front of us

00:09:53.615 --> 00:09:55.728
and a group of friends working with us.

00:09:56.153 --> 00:09:58.399
All we wanted to do
was stop those plastic bags

00:09:58.423 --> 00:10:01.065
from wrapping and suffocating
our beautiful home.

00:10:01.891 --> 00:10:03.599
Kids have a boundless energy

00:10:03.623 --> 00:10:07.788
and a motivation to be the change
the world needs.

00:10:08.412 --> 00:10:13.137
IW: So to all the kids of this beautiful
but challenging world:

00:10:13.648 --> 00:10:14.802
go for it!

00:10:14.826 --> 00:10:16.581
Make that difference.

00:10:17.015 --> 00:10:19.434
We're not telling you
it's going to be easy.

00:10:19.458 --> 00:10:21.725
We're telling you
it's going to be worth it.

00:10:22.179 --> 00:10:26.550
Us kids may only be 25 percent
of the world's population,

00:10:26.574 --> 00:10:29.881
but we are 100 percent of the future.

00:10:31.008 --> 00:10:33.664
MW: We still have a lot of work to do,

00:10:33.688 --> 00:10:35.353
but know that we still not stop

00:10:35.377 --> 00:10:39.802
until the first question asked
when arriving at the Bali airports will be

00:10:40.640 --> 00:10:41.974
Both: "Welcome to Bali,

00:10:41.998 --> 00:10:44.165
do you have nay plastic bags to declare?"

00:10:44.189 --> 00:10:45.602
(Laughter)

00:10:45.626 --> 00:10:48.362
Om shanti shanti shanti om.

00:10:48.386 --> 00:10:49.537
Thank you.

00:10:49.561 --> 00:10:59.354
(Applause)

title: A delightful way to teach kids about computers
transcript: Code is the next universal language. In the seventies, it was punk music that drove the whole generation. In the eighties, it was probably money. But for my generation of people, software is the interface to our imagination and our world. And that means that we need a radically, radically more diverse set of people to build those products, to not see computers as mechanical and lonely and boring and magic, to see them as things that they can tinker and turn around and twist, and so forth.My personal journey into the world of programming and technology started at the tender age of 14. I had this mad teenage crush on an older man, and the older man in question just happened to be the then Vice President of the United States, Mr. Al Gore. And I did what every single teenage girl would want to do. I wanted to somehow express all of this love, so I built him a website, it's over here. And in 2001, there was no Tumblr, there was no Facebook, there was no Pinterest. So I needed to learn to code in order to express all of this longing and loving.And that is how programming started for me. It started as a means of self-expression. Just like when I was smaller, I would use crayons and legos. And when I was older, I would use guitar lessons and theater plays. But then, there were other things to get excited about, like poetry and knitting socks and conjugating French irregular verbs and coming up with make-believe worlds and Bertrand Russell and his philosophy. And I started to be one of those people who felt that computers are boring and technical and lonely.Here's what I think today. Little girls don't know that they are not supposed to like computers. Little girls are amazing. They are really, really good at concentrating on things and being exact and they ask amazing questions like, "What?" and "Why?" and "How?" and "What if?" And they don't know that they are not supposed to like computers. It's the parents who do. It's us parents who feel like computer science is this esoteric, weird science discipline that only belongs to the mystery makers. That it's almost as far removed from everyday life as, say, nuclear physics.And they are partly right about that. There's a lot of syntax and controls and data structures and algorithms and practices, protocols and paradigms in programming. And we as a community, we've made computers smaller and smaller. We've built layers and layers of abstraction on top of each other between the man and the machine to the point that we no longer have any idea how computers work or how to talk to them. And we do teach our kids how the human body works, we teach them how the combustion engine functions and we even tell them that if you want to really be an astronaut you can become one. But when the kid comes to us and asks, "So, what is a bubble sort algorithm?" Or, "How does the computer know what happens when I press 'play,' how does it know which video to show?" Or, "Linda, is Internet a place?" We adults, we grow oddly silent. "It's magic," some of us say. "It's too complicated," the others say.Well, it's neither. It's not magic and it's not complicated. It all just happened really, really, really fast. Computer scientists built these amazing, beautiful machines, but they made them very, very foreign to us, and also the language we speak to the computers so that we don't know how to speak to the computers anymore without our fancy user interfaces.And that's why no one recognized that when I was conjugating French irregular verbs, I was actually practicing my pattern recognition skills. And when I was excited about knitting, I actually was following a sequence of symbolic commands that included loops inside of them. And that Bertrand Russell's lifelong quest to find an exact language between English and mathematics found its home inside of a computer. I was a programmer, but no one knew it.The kids of today, they tap, swipe and pinch their way through the world. But unless we give them tools to build with computers, we are raising only consumers instead of creators.This whole quest led me to this little girl. Her name is Ruby, she is six years old. She is completely fearless, imaginative and a little bit bossy. And every time I would run into a problem in trying to teach myself programming like, "What is object-oriented design or what is garbage collection?", I would try to imagine how a six-year-old little girl would explain the problem.And I wrote a book about her and I illustrated it and the things Ruby taught me go like this. Ruby taught me that you're not supposed to be afraid of the bugs under your bed. And even the biggest of the problems are a group of tiny problems stuck together. And Ruby also introduced me to her friends, the colorful side of the Internet culture. She has friends like the Snow Leopard, who is beautiful but doesn't want to play with the other kids. And she has friends like the green robots that are really friendly but super messy. And she has friends like Linux the penguin who's really ruthlessly efficient, but somewhat hard to understand. And idealistic foxes, and so on.In Ruby's world, you learn technology through play. And, for instance, computers are really good at repeating stuff, so the way Ruby would teach loops goes like this. This is Ruby's favorite dance move, it goes, "Clap, clap, stomp, stomp clap, clap and jump." And you learn counter loops by repeating that four times. And you learn while loops by repeating that sequence while I'm standing on one leg. And you learn until loops by repeating that sequence until mom gets really mad. (Laughter) And most of all, you learn that there are no ready answers.When coming up with the curriculum for Ruby's world, I needed to really ask the kids how they see the world and what kind of questions they have and I would organize play testing sessions. I would start by showing the kids these four pictures. I would show them a picture of a car, a grocery store, a dog and a toilet. And I would ask, "Which one of these do you think is a computer?" And the kids would be very conservative and go, "None of these is a computer. I know what a computer is: it's that glowing box in front of which mom or dad spends way too much time." But then we would talk and we would discover that actually, a car is a computer, it has a navigation system inside of it. And a dog — a dog might not be a computer, but it has a collar and the collar might have a computer inside of it. And grocery stores, they have so many different kinds of computers, like the cashier system and the burglar alarms. And kids, you know what? In Japan, toilets are computers and there's even hackers who hack them. (Laughter)And we go further and I give them these little stickers with an on/off button on them. And I tell the kids, "Today you have this magic ability to make anything in this room into a computer." And again, the kids go, "Sounds really hard, I don't know the right answer for this." But I tell them, "Don't worry, your parents don't know the right answer, either. They've just started to hear about this thing called The Internet of Things. But you kids, you are going to be the ones who are really going to live up in a world where everything is a computer."And then I had this little girl who came to me and took a bicycle lamp and she said, "This bicycle lamp, if it were a computer, it would change colors." And I said, "That's a really good idea, what else could it do?" And she thinks and she thinks, and she goes, "If this bicycle lamp were a computer, we could go on a biking trip with my father and we would sleep in a tent and this biking lamp could also be a movie projector." And that's the moment I'm looking for, the moment when the kid realizes that the world is definitely not ready yet, that a really awesome way of making the world more ready is by building technology and that each one of us can be a part of that change.Final story, we also built a computer. And we got to know the bossy CPU and the helpful RAM and ROM that help it remember things. And after we've assembled our computer together, we also design an application for it. And my favorite story is this little boy, he's six years old and his favorite thing in the world is to be an astronaut. And the boy, he has these huge headphones on and he's completely immersed in his tiny paper computer because you see, he's built his own intergalactic planetary navigation application. And his father, the lone astronaut in the Martian orbit, is on the other side of the room and the boy's important mission is to bring the father safely back to earth. And these kids are going to have a profoundly different view of the world and the way we build it with technology.Finally, the more approachable, the more inclusive, and the more diverse we make the world of technology, the more colorful and better the world will look like. So, imagine with me, for a moment, a world where the stories we tell about how things get made don't only include the twentysomething-year-old Silicon Valley boys, but also Kenyan schoolgirls and Norwegian librarians. Imagine a world where the little Ada Lovelaces of tomorrow, who live in a permanent reality of 1s and 0s, they grow up to be very optimistic and brave about technology. They embrace the powers and the opportunities and the limitations of the world. A world of technology that is wonderful, whimsical and a tiny bit weird.When I was a girl, I wanted to be a storyteller. I loved make-believe worlds and my favorite thing to do was to wake up in the mornings in Moominvalley. In the afternoons, I would roam around the Tatooines. And in the evenings, I would go to sleep in Narnia. And programming turned out to be the perfect profession for me. I still create worlds. Instead of stories, I do them with code.Programming gives me this amazing power to build my whole little universe with its own rules and paradigms and practices. Create something out of nothing with the pure power of logic.Thank you.(Applause)

Just like when I was smaller,
I would use crayons and legos.

00:01:32.678 --> 00:01:37.278
And when I was older, I would use
guitar lessons and theater plays.

00:01:37.878 --> 00:01:40.854
But then, there were other things
to get excited about,

00:01:40.878 --> 00:01:43.294
like poetry and knitting socks

00:01:43.318 --> 00:01:46.614
and conjugating French irregular verbs

00:01:46.638 --> 00:01:48.494
and coming up with make-believe worlds

00:01:48.518 --> 00:01:51.654
and Bertrand Russell and his philosophy.

00:01:51.678 --> 00:01:53.574
And I started to be one of those people

00:01:53.598 --> 00:01:57.278
who felt that computers
are boring and technical and lonely.

00:01:58.078 --> 00:01:59.894
Here's what I think today.

00:01:59.918 --> 00:02:03.974
Little girls don't know that they
are not supposed to like computers.

00:02:03.998 --> 00:02:05.254
Little girls are amazing.

00:02:05.278 --> 00:02:09.414
They are really, really good
at concentrating on things

00:02:09.438 --> 00:02:12.694
and being exact and they ask
amazing questions like,

00:02:12.718 --> 00:02:15.294
"What?" and "Why?"
and "How?" and "What if?"

00:02:15.318 --> 00:02:18.998
And they don't know that they
are not supposed to like computers.

00:02:19.718 --> 00:02:21.654
It's the parents who do.

00:02:21.678 --> 00:02:22.973
It's us parents who feel

00:02:22.997 --> 00:02:28.094
like computer science
is this esoteric, weird science discipline

00:02:28.118 --> 00:02:31.774
that only belongs to the mystery makers.

00:02:31.798 --> 00:02:34.534
That it's almost as far removed
from everyday life

00:02:34.558 --> 00:02:37.094
as, say, nuclear physics.

00:02:37.118 --> 00:02:39.574
And they are partly right about that.

00:02:39.598 --> 00:02:43.094
There's a lot of syntax
and controls and data structures

00:02:43.118 --> 00:02:45.774
and algorithms and practices,

00:02:45.798 --> 00:02:48.374
protocols and paradigms in programming.

00:02:48.398 --> 00:02:52.694
And we as a community,
we've made computers smaller and smaller.

00:02:52.718 --> 00:02:57.254
We've built layers and layers
of abstraction on top of each other

00:02:57.278 --> 00:02:58.774
between the man and the machine

00:02:58.798 --> 00:03:02.014
to the point that we no longer
have any idea how computers work

00:03:02.038 --> 00:03:04.214
or how to talk to them.

00:03:04.238 --> 00:03:07.014
And we do teach our kids
how the human body works,

00:03:07.038 --> 00:03:10.134
we teach them how
the combustion engine functions

00:03:10.158 --> 00:03:13.174
and we even tell them
that if you want to really be an astronaut

00:03:13.198 --> 00:03:14.654
you can become one.

00:03:14.678 --> 00:03:16.854
But when the kid comes to us and asks,

00:03:16.878 --> 00:03:19.614
"So, what is a bubble sort algorithm?"

00:03:19.638 --> 00:03:24.054
Or, "How does the computer know
what happens when I press 'play,'

00:03:24.078 --> 00:03:25.934
how does it know which video to show?"

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.534
Or, "Linda, is Internet a place?"

00:03:28.558 --> 00:03:31.278
We adults, we grow oddly silent.

00:03:32.358 --> 00:03:34.814
"It's magic," some of us say.

00:03:34.838 --> 00:03:37.558
"It's too complicated," the others say.

00:03:38.478 --> 00:03:39.974
Well, it's neither.

00:03:39.998 --> 00:03:42.574
It's not magic and it's not complicated.

00:03:42.598 --> 00:03:46.214
It all just happened
really, really, really fast.

00:03:46.238 --> 00:03:49.134
Computer scientists built
these amazing, beautiful machines,

00:03:49.158 --> 00:03:51.574
but they made them
very, very foreign to us,

00:03:51.598 --> 00:03:53.814
and also the language we speak
to the computers

00:03:53.838 --> 00:03:56.854
so that we don't know
how to speak to the computers anymore

00:03:56.878 --> 00:03:59.374
without our fancy user interfaces.

00:03:59.398 --> 00:04:00.974
And that's why no one recognized

00:04:00.998 --> 00:04:03.694
that when I was conjugating
French irregular verbs,

00:04:03.718 --> 00:04:06.974
I was actually practicing
my pattern recognition skills.

00:04:06.998 --> 00:04:09.294
And when I was excited about knitting,

00:04:09.318 --> 00:04:12.854
I actually was following
a sequence of symbolic commands

00:04:12.878 --> 00:04:14.614
that included loops inside of them.

00:04:14.638 --> 00:04:17.054
And that Bertrand Russell's lifelong quest

00:04:17.078 --> 00:04:21.054
to find an exact language
between English and mathematics

00:04:21.078 --> 00:04:23.398
found its home inside of a computer.

00:04:24.038 --> 00:04:26.238
I was a programmer, but no one knew it.

00:04:27.038 --> 00:04:31.494
The kids of today, they tap, swipe
and pinch their way through the world.

00:04:31.518 --> 00:04:34.734
But unless we give them tools
to build with computers,

00:04:34.758 --> 00:04:38.694
we are raising only consumers
instead of creators.

00:04:38.718 --> 00:04:41.254
This whole quest
led me to this little girl.

00:04:41.278 --> 00:04:43.654
Her name is Ruby, she is six years old.

00:04:43.678 --> 00:04:47.774
She is completely fearless,
imaginative and a little bit bossy.

00:04:47.798 --> 00:04:50.254
And every time
I would run into a problem

00:04:50.278 --> 00:04:52.534
in trying to teach
myself programming like,

00:04:52.558 --> 00:04:56.534
"What is object-oriented design
or what is garbage collection?",

00:04:56.558 --> 00:05:00.974
I would try to imagine how a six-year-old
little girl would explain the problem.

00:05:00.998 --> 00:05:03.654
And I wrote a book about her
and I illustrated it

00:05:03.678 --> 00:05:06.054
and the things
Ruby taught me go like this.

00:05:06.078 --> 00:05:08.534
Ruby taught me that you're
not supposed to be afraid

00:05:08.558 --> 00:05:09.934
of the bugs under your bed.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.014
And even the biggest of the problems

00:05:12.038 --> 00:05:15.534
are a group of tiny problems
stuck together.

00:05:15.558 --> 00:05:18.294
And Ruby also introduced
me to her friends,

00:05:18.318 --> 00:05:21.214
the colorful side of the Internet culture.

00:05:21.238 --> 00:05:23.094
She has friends like the Snow Leopard,

00:05:23.118 --> 00:05:26.054
who is beautiful but doesn't want
to play with the other kids.

00:05:26.078 --> 00:05:30.694
And she has friends like the green robots
that are really friendly but super messy.

00:05:30.718 --> 00:05:32.894
And she has friends like Linux the penguin

00:05:32.918 --> 00:05:36.574
who's really ruthlessly efficient,
but somewhat hard to understand.

00:05:36.598 --> 00:05:38.838
And idealistic foxes, and so on.

00:05:39.838 --> 00:05:43.494
In Ruby's world, you learn
technology through play.

00:05:43.518 --> 00:05:46.734
And, for instance, computers
are really good at repeating stuff,

00:05:46.758 --> 00:05:49.654
so the way Ruby would teach
loops goes like this.

00:05:49.678 --> 00:05:53.054
This is Ruby's favorite dance move,
it goes, "Clap, clap, stomp, stomp

00:05:53.078 --> 00:05:54.574
clap, clap and jump."

00:05:54.598 --> 00:05:58.614
And you learn counter loops
by repeating that four times.

00:05:58.638 --> 00:06:01.454
And you learn while loops
by repeating that sequence

00:06:01.478 --> 00:06:03.254
while I'm standing on one leg.

00:06:03.278 --> 00:06:06.574
And you learn until loops
by repeating that sequence

00:06:06.598 --> 00:06:08.654
until mom gets really mad.

00:06:08.678 --> 00:06:09.694
(Laughter)

00:06:09.718 --> 00:06:13.438
And most of all, you learn
that there are no ready answers.

00:06:14.278 --> 00:06:17.014
When coming up with the curriculum
for Ruby's world,

00:06:17.038 --> 00:06:20.334
I needed to really ask the kids
how they see the world

00:06:20.358 --> 00:06:22.374
and what kind of questions they have

00:06:22.398 --> 00:06:24.478
and I would organize
play testing sessions.

00:06:25.318 --> 00:06:27.878
I would start by showing the kids
these four pictures.

00:06:28.438 --> 00:06:30.774
I would show them a picture of a car,

00:06:30.798 --> 00:06:33.214
a grocery store, a dog and a toilet.

00:06:33.238 --> 00:06:36.478
And I would ask, "Which one of these
do you think is a computer?"

00:06:37.438 --> 00:06:40.174
And the kids would be
very conservative and go,

00:06:40.198 --> 00:06:41.974
"None of these is a computer.

00:06:41.998 --> 00:06:43.654
I know what a computer is:

00:06:43.678 --> 00:06:45.014
it's that glowing box

00:06:45.038 --> 00:06:48.654
in front of which mom or dad
spends way too much time."

00:06:48.678 --> 00:06:50.174
But then we would talk

00:06:50.198 --> 00:06:53.014
and we would discover
that actually, a car is a computer,

00:06:53.038 --> 00:06:55.414
it has a navigation system inside of it.

00:06:55.438 --> 00:06:58.214
And a dog -- a dog
might not be a computer,

00:06:58.238 --> 00:06:59.454
but it has a collar

00:06:59.478 --> 00:07:02.094
and the collar might have
a computer inside of it.

00:07:02.118 --> 00:07:05.574
And grocery stores, they have
so many different kinds of computers,

00:07:05.598 --> 00:07:09.014
like the cashier system
and the burglar alarms.

00:07:09.038 --> 00:07:10.374
And kids, you know what?

00:07:10.398 --> 00:07:12.934
In Japan, toilets are computers

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.854
and there's even hackers who hack them.

00:07:14.878 --> 00:07:16.654
(Laughter)

00:07:16.678 --> 00:07:17.894
And we go further

00:07:17.918 --> 00:07:21.134
and I give them these little stickers
with an on/off button on them.

00:07:21.158 --> 00:07:24.774
And I tell the kids,
"Today you have this magic ability

00:07:24.798 --> 00:07:28.414
to make anything in this room
into a computer."

00:07:28.438 --> 00:07:29.774
And again, the kids go,

00:07:29.798 --> 00:07:32.694
"Sounds really hard,
I don't know the right answer for this."

00:07:32.718 --> 00:07:34.294
But I tell them, "Don't worry,

00:07:34.318 --> 00:07:36.894
your parents don't know
the right answer, either.

00:07:36.918 --> 00:07:39.134
They've just started
to hear about this thing

00:07:39.158 --> 00:07:41.374
called The Internet of Things.

00:07:41.398 --> 00:07:43.374
But you kids,
you are going to be the ones

00:07:43.398 --> 00:07:47.774
who are really going to live up in a world
where everything is a computer."

00:07:47.798 --> 00:07:50.014
And then I had this little girl
who came to me

00:07:50.038 --> 00:07:51.334
and took a bicycle lamp

00:07:51.358 --> 00:07:55.574
and she said, "This bicycle lamp,
if it were a computer,

00:07:55.598 --> 00:07:57.614
it would change colors."

00:07:57.638 --> 00:08:00.654
And I said, "That's a really good idea,
what else could it do?"

00:08:00.678 --> 00:08:02.414
And she thinks and she thinks,

00:08:02.438 --> 00:08:06.454
and she goes, "If this bicycle lamp
were a computer,

00:08:06.478 --> 00:08:09.214
we could go on a biking trip
with my father

00:08:09.238 --> 00:08:10.854
and we would sleep in a tent

00:08:10.878 --> 00:08:14.718
and this biking lamp
could also be a movie projector."

00:08:15.598 --> 00:08:17.558
And that's the moment I'm looking for,

00:08:18.358 --> 00:08:19.934
the moment when the kid realizes

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.334
that the world
is definitely not ready yet,

00:08:22.358 --> 00:08:25.334
that a really awesome way
of making the world more ready

00:08:25.358 --> 00:08:27.574
is by building technology

00:08:27.598 --> 00:08:30.358
and that each one of us
can be a part of that change.

00:08:31.158 --> 00:08:34.214
Final story, we also built a computer.

00:08:34.238 --> 00:08:38.974
And we got to know the bossy CPU
and the helpful RAM and ROM

00:08:38.998 --> 00:08:40.414
that help it remember things.

00:08:40.438 --> 00:08:43.374
And after we've assembled
our computer together,

00:08:43.398 --> 00:08:46.054
we also design an application for it.

00:08:46.078 --> 00:08:48.093
And my favorite story is this little boy,

00:08:48.117 --> 00:08:49.374
he's six years old

00:08:49.398 --> 00:08:52.517
and his favorite thing in the world
is to be an astronaut.

00:08:53.078 --> 00:08:55.334
And the boy, he has
these huge headphones on

00:08:55.358 --> 00:08:58.614
and he's completely immersed
in his tiny paper computer

00:08:58.638 --> 00:09:00.654
because you see, he's built his own

00:09:00.678 --> 00:09:04.974
intergalactic planetary
navigation application.

00:09:04.998 --> 00:09:08.134
And his father, the lone astronaut
in the Martian orbit,

00:09:08.158 --> 00:09:10.014
is on the other side of the room

00:09:10.038 --> 00:09:11.654
and the boy's important mission

00:09:11.678 --> 00:09:14.598
is to bring the father
safely back to earth.

00:09:15.718 --> 00:09:19.174
And these kids are going to have
a profoundly different view of the world

00:09:19.198 --> 00:09:21.598
and the way we build it with technology.

00:09:22.798 --> 00:09:26.654
Finally, the more approachable,
the more inclusive,

00:09:26.678 --> 00:09:30.054
and the more diverse
we make the world of technology,

00:09:30.078 --> 00:09:34.054
the more colorful and better
the world will look like.

00:09:34.078 --> 00:09:36.654
So, imagine with me, for a moment,

00:09:36.678 --> 00:09:39.254
a world where the stories we tell

00:09:39.278 --> 00:09:42.294
about how things get made
don't only include

00:09:42.318 --> 00:09:44.734
the twentysomething-year-old
Silicon Valley boys,

00:09:44.758 --> 00:09:49.158
but also Kenyan schoolgirls
and Norwegian librarians.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:54.174
Imagine a world where
the little Ada Lovelaces of tomorrow,

00:09:54.198 --> 00:09:57.414
who live in a permanent
reality of 1s and 0s,

00:09:57.438 --> 00:10:02.054
they grow up to be very optimistic
and brave about technology.

00:10:02.078 --> 00:10:05.454
They embrace the powers
and the opportunities

00:10:05.478 --> 00:10:07.078
and the limitations of the world.

00:10:07.638 --> 00:10:11.774
A world of technology
that is wonderful, whimsical

00:10:11.798 --> 00:10:13.438
and a tiny bit weird.

00:10:15.078 --> 00:10:16.574
When I was a girl,

00:10:16.598 --> 00:10:18.614
I wanted to be a storyteller.

00:10:18.638 --> 00:10:20.214
I loved make-believe worlds

00:10:20.238 --> 00:10:21.854
and my favorite thing to do

00:10:21.878 --> 00:10:25.934
was to wake up in the mornings
in Moominvalley.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:29.078
In the afternoons,
I would roam around the Tatooines.

00:10:29.278 --> 00:10:32.158
And in the evenings,
I would go to sleep in Narnia.

00:10:33.358 --> 00:10:36.558
And programming turned out
to be the perfect profession for me.

00:10:37.678 --> 00:10:39.614
I still create worlds.

00:10:39.638 --> 00:10:42.598
Instead of stories, I do them with code.

00:10:43.598 --> 00:10:46.654
Programming gives me this amazing power

00:10:46.678 --> 00:10:49.054
to build my whole little universe

00:10:49.078 --> 00:10:53.038
with its own rules
and paradigms and practices.

00:10:54.078 --> 00:10:58.038
Create something out of nothing
with the pure power of logic.

00:10:58.878 --> 00:11:00.094
Thank you.

00:11:00.118 --> 00:11:02.558
(Applause)

title: The boiling river of the Amazon
transcript: As a boy in Lima, my grandfather told me a legend of the Spanish conquest of Peru. Atahualpa, emperor of the Inca, had been captured and killed. Pizarro and his conquistadors had grown rich, and tales of their conquest and glory had reached Spain and was bringing new waves of Spaniards, hungry for gold and glory. They would go into towns and ask the Inca, "Where's another civilization we can conquer? Where's more gold?"And the Inca, out of vengeance, told them, "Go to the Amazon. You'll find all the gold you want there. In fact, there is a city called Paititi — El Dorado in Spanish — made entirely of gold."The Spanish set off into the jungle, but the few that return come back with stories, stories of powerful shamans, of warriors with poisoned arrows, of trees so tall they blotted out the sun, spiders that ate birds, snakes that swallowed men whole and a river that boiled.All this became a childhood memory. And years passed. I'm working on my PhD at SMU, trying to understand Peru's geothermal energy potential, when I remember this legend, and I began asking that question. Could the boiling river exist?I asked colleagues from universities, the government, oil, gas and mining companies, and the answer was a unanimous no. And this makes sense. You see, boiling rivers do exist in the world, but they're generally associated with volcanoes. You need a powerful heat source to produce such a large geothermal manifestation. And as you can see from the red dots here, which are volcanoes, we don't have volcanoes in the Amazon, nor in most of Peru. So it follows: We should not expect to see a boiling river.Telling this same story at a family dinner, my aunt tells me, "But no, Andrés, I've been there. I've swum in that river."(Laughter)Then my uncle jumps in. "No, Andrés, she's not kidding. You see, you can only swim in it after a very heavy rain, and it's protected by a powerful shaman. Your aunt, she's friends with his wife."(Laughter)"¿Cómo?" ["Huh?"]You know, despite all my scientific skepticism, I found myself hiking into the jungle, guided by my aunt, over 700 kilometers away from the nearest volcanic center, and well, honestly, mentally preparing myself to behold the legendary "warm stream of the Amazon."But then ... I heard something, a low surge that got louder and louder as we came closer. It sounded like ocean waves constantly crashing, and as we got closer, I saw smoke, vapor, coming up through the trees. And then, I saw this.I immediately grabbed for my thermometer, and the average temperatures in the river were 86 degrees C. This is not quite the 100-degree C boiling but definitely close enough. The river flowed hot and fast. I followed it upriver and was led by, actually, the shaman's apprentice to the most sacred site on the river. And this is what's bizarre — It starts off as a cold stream. And here, at this site, is the home of the Yacumama, mother of the waters, a giant serpent spirit who births hot and cold water. And here we find a hot spring, mixing with cold stream water underneath her protective motherly jaws and thus bringing their legends to life.The next morning, I woke up and —(Laughter)I asked for tea. I was handed a mug, a tea bag and, well, pointed towards the river. To my surprise, the water was clean and had a pleasant taste, which is a little weird for geothermal systems.What was amazing is that the locals had always known about this place, and that I was by no means the first outsider to see it. It was just part of their everyday life. They drink its water. They take in its vapor. They cook with it, clean with it, even make their medicines with it.I met the shaman, and he seemed like an extension of the river and his jungle. He asked for my intentions and listened carefully. Then, to my tremendous relief — I was freaking out, to be honest with you — a smile began to snake across his face, and he just laughed.(Laughter)I had received the shaman's blessing to study the river, on the condition that after I take the water samples and analyze them in my lab, wherever I was in the world, that I pour the waters back into the ground so that, as the shaman said, the waters could find their way back home.I've been back every year since that first visit in 2011, and the fieldwork has been exhilarating, demanding and at times dangerous. One story was even featured in National Geographic Magazine. I was trapped on a small rock about the size of a sheet of paper in sandals and board shorts, in between an 80 degree C river and a hot spring that, well, looked like this, close to boiling. And on top of that, it was Amazon rain forest. Pshh, pouring rain, couldn't see a thing. The temperature differential made it all white. It was a whiteout. Intense.Now, after years of work, I'll soon be submitting my geophysical and geochemical studies for publication. And I'd like to share, today, with all of you here, on the TED stage, for the first time, some of these discoveries.Well, first off, it's not a legend. Surprise!(Laughter)When I first started the research, the satellite imagery was too low-resolution to be meaningful. There were just no good maps. Thanks to the support of the Google Earth team, I now have this. Not only that, the indigenous name of the river, Shanay-timpishka, "boiled with the heat of the sun," indicating that I'm not the first to wonder why the river boils, and showing that humanity has always sought to explain the world around us.So why does the river boil?(Bubbling sounds)It actually took me three years to get that footage.Fault-fed hot springs. As we have hot blood running through our veins and arteries, so, too, the earth has hot water running through its cracks and faults. Where these arteries come to the surface, these earth arteries, we'll get geothermal manifestations: fumaroles, hot springs and in our case, the boiling river.What's truly incredible, though, is the scale of this place. Next time you cross the road, think about this. The river flows wider than a two-lane road along most of its path. It flows hot for 6.24 kilometers. Truly impressive. There are thermal pools larger than this TED stage, and that waterfall that you see there is six meters tall — and all with near-boiling water.We mapped the temperatures along the river, and this was by far the most demanding part of the fieldwork. And the results were just awesome. Sorry — the geoscientist in me coming out. And it showed this amazing trend. You see, the river starts off cold. It then heats up, cools back down, heats up, cools back down, heats up again, and then has this beautiful decay curve until it smashes into this cold river.Now, I understand not all of you are geothermal scientists, so to put it in more everyday terms: Everyone loves coffee. Yes? Good. Your regular cup of coffee, 54 degrees C, an extra-hot one, well, 60. So, put in coffee shop terms, the boiling river plots like this. There you have your hot coffee. Here you have your extra-hot coffee, and you can see that there's a bit point there where the river is still hotter than even the extra-hot coffee. And these are average water temperatures. We took these in the dry season to ensure the purest geothermal temperatures.But there's a magic number here that's not being shown, and that number is 47 degrees C, because that's where things start to hurt, and I know this from very personal experience. Above that temperature, you don't want to get in that water. You need to be careful. It can be deadly.I've seen all sorts of animals fall in, and what's shocking to me, is the process is pretty much the same. So they fall in and the first thing to go are the eyes. Eyes, apparently, cook very quickly. They turn this milky-white color. The stream is carrying them. They're trying to swim out, but their meat is cooking on the bone because it's so hot. So they're losing power, losing power, until finally they get to a point where hot water goes into their mouths and they cook from the inside out.(Laughter)A bit sadistic, aren't we? Jeez. Leave them marinating for a little longer. What's, again, amazing are these temperatures. They're similar to things that I've seen on volcanoes all over the world and even super-volcanoes like Yellowstone.But here's the thing: the data is showing that the boiling river exists independent of volcanism. It's neither magmatic or volcanic in origin, and again, over 700 kilometers away from the nearest volcanic center.How can a boiling river exist like this? I've asked geothermal experts and volcanologists for years, and I'm still unable to find another non-volcanic geothermal system of this magnitude. It's unique. It's special on a global scale. So, still — how does it work? Where do we get this heat? There's still more research to be done to better constrain the problem and better understand the system, but from what the data is telling us now, it looks to be the result of a large hydrothermal system.Basically, it works like this: So, the deeper you go into the earth, the hotter it gets. We refer to this as the geothermal gradient. The waters could be coming from as far away as glaciers in the Andes, then seeping down deep into the earth and coming out to form the boiling river after getting heated up from the geothermal gradient, all due to this unique geologic setting.Now, we found that in and around the river — this is working with colleagues from National Geographic, Dr. Spencer Wells, and Dr. Jon Eisen from UC Davis — we genetically sequenced the extremophile lifeforms living in and around the river, and have found new lifeforms, unique species living in the boiling river.But again, despite all of these studies, all of these discoveries and the legends, a question remains: What is the significance of the boiling river? What is the significance of this stationary cloud that always hovers over this patch of jungle? And what is the significance of a detail in a childhood legend?To the shaman and his community, it's a sacred site. To me, as a geoscientist, it's a unique geothermal phenomenon. But to the illegal loggers and cattle farmers, it's just another resource to exploit. And to the Peruvian government, it's just another stretch of unprotected land ready for development.My goal is to ensure that whoever controls this land understands the boiling river's uniqueness and significance. Because that's the question, one of significance. And the thing there is, we define significance. It's us. We have that power. We are the ones who draw that line between the sacred and the trivial. And in this age, where everything seems mapped, measured and studied, in this age of information, I remind you all that discoveries are not just made in the black void of the unknown but in the white noise of overwhelming data.There remains so much to explore. We live in an incredible world. So go out. Be curious. Because we do live in a world where shamans still sing to the spirits of the jungle, where rivers do boil and where legends do come to life.Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.981 --> 00:00:14.624
As a boy in Lima,

00:00:14.648 --> 00:00:16.759
my grandfather told me a legend

00:00:16.783 --> 00:00:19.037
of the Spanish conquest of Peru.

00:00:19.965 --> 00:00:23.504
Atahualpa, emperor of the Inca,
had been captured and killed.

00:00:23.528 --> 00:00:26.511
Pizarro and his conquistadors
had grown rich,

00:00:26.535 --> 00:00:29.721
and tales of their conquest
and glory had reached Spain

00:00:29.745 --> 00:00:35.120
and was bringing new waves of Spaniards,
hungry for gold and glory.

00:00:36.013 --> 00:00:38.911
They would go into towns and ask the Inca,

00:00:38.935 --> 00:00:42.710
"Where's another civilization
we can conquer? Where's more gold?"

00:00:42.734 --> 00:00:46.113
And the Inca, out of vengeance, told them,

00:00:46.606 --> 00:00:48.215
"Go to the Amazon.

00:00:48.725 --> 00:00:51.371
You'll find all the gold you want there.

00:00:51.395 --> 00:00:56.109
In fact, there is a city called Paititi --
El Dorado in Spanish --

00:00:56.133 --> 00:00:58.760
made entirely of gold."

00:00:59.261 --> 00:01:01.157
The Spanish set off into the jungle,

00:01:01.181 --> 00:01:04.743
but the few that return
come back with stories,

00:01:05.862 --> 00:01:09.669
stories of powerful shamans,

00:01:09.693 --> 00:01:12.597
of warriors with poisoned arrows,

00:01:12.621 --> 00:01:16.399
of trees so tall they blotted out the sun,

00:01:16.423 --> 00:01:21.175
spiders that ate birds,
snakes that swallowed men whole

00:01:21.199 --> 00:01:23.483
and a river that boiled.

00:01:25.753 --> 00:01:27.737
All this became a childhood memory.

00:01:27.761 --> 00:01:28.920
And years passed.

00:01:28.944 --> 00:01:31.419
I'm working on my PhD at SMU,

00:01:31.443 --> 00:01:35.347
trying to understand
Peru's geothermal energy potential,

00:01:35.371 --> 00:01:37.417
when I remember this legend,

00:01:37.441 --> 00:01:39.290
and I began asking that question.

00:01:40.274 --> 00:01:42.821
Could the boiling river exist?

00:01:44.098 --> 00:01:46.297
I asked colleagues from universities,

00:01:46.321 --> 00:01:47.478
the government,

00:01:47.502 --> 00:01:48.995
oil, gas and mining companies,

00:01:49.019 --> 00:01:51.925
and the answer was a unanimous no.

00:01:52.417 --> 00:01:54.417
And this makes sense.

00:01:55.028 --> 00:01:57.656
You see, boiling rivers
do exist in the world,

00:01:57.680 --> 00:02:00.139
but they're generally
associated with volcanoes.

00:02:00.607 --> 00:02:02.754
You need a powerful heat source

00:02:02.778 --> 00:02:06.144
to produce such a large
geothermal manifestation.

00:02:06.168 --> 00:02:11.372
And as you can see from the red dots
here, which are volcanoes,

00:02:11.396 --> 00:02:14.214
we don't have volcanoes in the Amazon,

00:02:14.238 --> 00:02:16.056
nor in most of Peru.

00:02:16.080 --> 00:02:20.348
So it follows: We should not expect
to see a boiling river.

00:02:21.618 --> 00:02:25.706
Telling this same story
at a family dinner,

00:02:25.730 --> 00:02:28.200
my aunt tells me,

00:02:28.224 --> 00:02:32.206
"But no, Andrés, I've been there.
I've swum in that river."

00:02:32.856 --> 00:02:36.493
(Laughter)

00:02:36.517 --> 00:02:38.264
Then my uncle jumps in.

00:02:38.288 --> 00:02:41.018
"No, Andrés, she's not kidding.

00:02:41.042 --> 00:02:45.025
You see, you can only swim in it
after a very heavy rain,

00:02:45.049 --> 00:02:48.295
and it's protected by a powerful shaman.

00:02:48.319 --> 00:02:50.636
Your aunt, she's friends with his wife."

00:02:51.215 --> 00:02:53.020
(Laughter)

00:02:53.044 --> 00:02:54.195
"¿Cómo?" ["Huh?"]

00:02:54.219 --> 00:02:56.433
You know, despite all
my scientific skepticism,

00:02:56.457 --> 00:03:00.889
I found myself hiking into the jungle,
guided by my aunt,

00:03:00.913 --> 00:03:04.810
over 700 kilometers away
from the nearest volcanic center,

00:03:04.834 --> 00:03:08.452
and well, honestly,
mentally preparing myself

00:03:08.476 --> 00:03:12.852
to behold the legendary
"warm stream of the Amazon."

00:03:14.629 --> 00:03:16.250
But then ...

00:03:16.274 --> 00:03:17.596
I heard something,

00:03:19.213 --> 00:03:20.662
a low surge

00:03:22.305 --> 00:03:25.000
that got louder and louder

00:03:25.750 --> 00:03:27.218
as we came closer.

00:03:28.258 --> 00:03:32.186
It sounded like ocean waves
constantly crashing,

00:03:32.210 --> 00:03:36.895
and as we got closer, I saw smoke, vapor,
coming up through the trees.

00:03:36.919 --> 00:03:40.218
And then, I saw this.

00:03:41.749 --> 00:03:44.218
I immediately grabbed for my thermometer,

00:03:44.242 --> 00:03:47.519
and the average temperatures in the river

00:03:47.543 --> 00:03:49.530
were 86 degrees C.

00:03:51.498 --> 00:03:54.765
This is not quite
the 100-degree C boiling

00:03:54.789 --> 00:03:57.666
but definitely close enough.

00:03:58.254 --> 00:04:01.346
The river flowed hot and fast.

00:04:02.139 --> 00:04:05.787
I followed it upriver and was led by,
actually, the shaman's apprentice

00:04:05.811 --> 00:04:07.595
to the most sacred site on the river.

00:04:07.619 --> 00:04:09.025
And this is what's bizarre --

00:04:09.049 --> 00:04:11.031
It starts off as a cold stream.

00:04:11.460 --> 00:04:13.697
And here, at this site,

00:04:13.721 --> 00:04:15.888
is the home of the Yacumama,

00:04:15.912 --> 00:04:19.255
mother of the waters,
a giant serpent spirit

00:04:19.279 --> 00:04:21.352
who births hot and cold water.

00:04:21.973 --> 00:04:26.385
And here we find a hot spring,

00:04:26.409 --> 00:04:31.767
mixing with cold stream water
underneath her protective motherly jaws

00:04:31.791 --> 00:04:35.036
and thus bringing their legends to life.

00:04:36.241 --> 00:04:38.219
The next morning, I woke up and --

00:04:38.243 --> 00:04:40.462
(Laughter)

00:04:40.486 --> 00:04:42.517
I asked for tea.

00:04:42.541 --> 00:04:44.781
I was handed a mug, a tea bag

00:04:44.805 --> 00:04:47.133
and, well, pointed towards the river.

00:04:48.033 --> 00:04:52.542
To my surprise, the water was clean
and had a pleasant taste,

00:04:52.566 --> 00:04:55.560
which is a little weird
for geothermal systems.

00:04:56.399 --> 00:04:57.947
What was amazing

00:04:57.971 --> 00:05:00.955
is that the locals had always
known about this place,

00:05:00.979 --> 00:05:04.683
and that I was by no means
the first outsider to see it.

00:05:05.659 --> 00:05:08.596
It was just part of their everyday life.

00:05:09.073 --> 00:05:11.767
They drink its water.

00:05:11.791 --> 00:05:14.346
They take in its vapor.

00:05:14.370 --> 00:05:16.061
They cook with it,

00:05:16.085 --> 00:05:17.595
clean with it,

00:05:17.619 --> 00:05:19.417
even make their medicines with it.

00:05:21.052 --> 00:05:22.798
I met the shaman,

00:05:22.822 --> 00:05:27.011
and he seemed like an extension
of the river and his jungle.

00:05:27.806 --> 00:05:29.630
He asked for my intentions

00:05:30.567 --> 00:05:32.146
and listened carefully.

00:05:33.220 --> 00:05:36.331
Then, to my tremendous relief --

00:05:36.355 --> 00:05:39.902
I was freaking out,
to be honest with you --

00:05:39.926 --> 00:05:44.205
a smile began to snake across his face,
and he just laughed.

00:05:44.229 --> 00:05:46.526
(Laughter)

00:05:47.754 --> 00:05:52.349
I had received the shaman's blessing
to study the river,

00:05:52.373 --> 00:05:55.777
on the condition that after I take
the water samples

00:05:55.801 --> 00:05:57.317
and analyze them in my lab,

00:05:57.341 --> 00:05:59.151
wherever I was in the world,

00:06:00.223 --> 00:06:03.989
that I pour the waters
back into the ground

00:06:04.013 --> 00:06:06.060
so that, as the shaman said,

00:06:06.084 --> 00:06:08.829
the waters could find their way back home.

00:06:11.230 --> 00:06:14.817
I've been back every year
since that first visit in 2011,

00:06:14.841 --> 00:06:18.266
and the fieldwork has been exhilarating,

00:06:18.290 --> 00:06:22.087
demanding and at times dangerous.

00:06:22.871 --> 00:06:26.086
One story was even featured
in National Geographic Magazine.

00:06:26.110 --> 00:06:30.197
I was trapped on a small rock
about the size of a sheet of paper

00:06:30.221 --> 00:06:32.261
in sandals and board shorts,

00:06:32.285 --> 00:06:34.691
in between an 80 degree C river

00:06:34.715 --> 00:06:38.444
and a hot spring that, well,
looked like this, close to boiling.

00:06:39.028 --> 00:06:42.566
And on top of that,
it was Amazon rain forest.

00:06:43.164 --> 00:06:45.670
Pshh, pouring rain, couldn't see a thing.

00:06:45.694 --> 00:06:49.256
The temperature differential
made it all white. It was a whiteout.

00:06:50.914 --> 00:06:52.319
Intense.

00:06:54.116 --> 00:06:56.554
Now, after years of work,

00:06:56.578 --> 00:07:02.220
I'll soon be submitting my geophysical
and geochemical studies for publication.

00:07:03.005 --> 00:07:06.980
And I'd like to share, today,
with all of you here, on the TED stage,

00:07:07.004 --> 00:07:10.194
for the first time,
some of these discoveries.

00:07:11.298 --> 00:07:13.829
Well, first off, it's not a legend.

00:07:14.426 --> 00:07:15.600
Surprise!

00:07:15.624 --> 00:07:17.949
(Laughter)

00:07:17.973 --> 00:07:20.487
When I first started the research,

00:07:20.511 --> 00:07:23.490
the satellite imagery was too
low-resolution to be meaningful.

00:07:23.514 --> 00:07:25.142
There were just no good maps.

00:07:25.712 --> 00:07:28.103
Thanks to the support
of the Google Earth team,

00:07:28.127 --> 00:07:29.472
I now have this.

00:07:31.209 --> 00:07:36.559
Not only that, the indigenous name
of the river, Shanay-timpishka,

00:07:37.496 --> 00:07:40.226
"boiled with the heat of the sun,"

00:07:41.498 --> 00:07:46.877
indicating that I'm not the first
to wonder why the river boils,

00:07:46.901 --> 00:07:50.128
and showing that humanity
has always sought to explain

00:07:50.152 --> 00:07:51.691
the world around us.

00:07:53.484 --> 00:07:55.882
So why does the river boil?

00:07:55.906 --> 00:08:00.319
(Bubbling sounds)

00:08:00.343 --> 00:08:02.838
It actually took me three years
to get that footage.

00:08:04.837 --> 00:08:06.442
Fault-fed hot springs.

00:08:07.583 --> 00:08:11.216
As we have hot blood running
through our veins and arteries,

00:08:11.240 --> 00:08:16.288
so, too, the earth has hot water
running through its cracks and faults.

00:08:17.120 --> 00:08:20.715
Where these arteries come to the surface,
these earth arteries,

00:08:20.739 --> 00:08:23.113
we'll get geothermal manifestations:

00:08:23.137 --> 00:08:27.157
fumaroles, hot springs
and in our case, the boiling river.

00:08:28.417 --> 00:08:32.517
What's truly incredible, though,
is the scale of this place.

00:08:33.179 --> 00:08:35.525
Next time you cross the road,
think about this.

00:08:36.485 --> 00:08:39.157
The river flows wider than a two-lane road

00:08:39.181 --> 00:08:41.045
along most of its path.

00:08:41.632 --> 00:08:46.975
It flows hot for 6.24 kilometers.

00:08:48.181 --> 00:08:49.690
Truly impressive.

00:08:51.035 --> 00:08:54.035
There are thermal pools
larger than this TED stage,

00:08:54.059 --> 00:08:56.535
and that waterfall that you see there

00:08:56.559 --> 00:08:58.597
is six meters tall --

00:08:59.342 --> 00:09:02.634
and all with near-boiling water.

00:09:04.201 --> 00:09:06.257
We mapped the temperatures
along the river,

00:09:06.281 --> 00:09:09.399
and this was by far the most
demanding part of the fieldwork.

00:09:09.824 --> 00:09:13.511
And the results were just awesome.

00:09:13.535 --> 00:09:16.688
Sorry -- the geoscientist
in me coming out.

00:09:16.712 --> 00:09:19.138
And it showed this amazing trend.

00:09:19.162 --> 00:09:21.378
You see, the river starts off cold.

00:09:21.402 --> 00:09:24.397
It then heats up, cools back down,
heats up, cools back down,

00:09:24.421 --> 00:09:27.039
heats up again, and then has
this beautiful decay curve

00:09:27.063 --> 00:09:29.435
until it smashes into this cold river.

00:09:30.497 --> 00:09:33.291
Now, I understand not all of you
are geothermal scientists,

00:09:33.315 --> 00:09:35.540
so to put it in more everyday terms:

00:09:36.183 --> 00:09:38.316
Everyone loves coffee.

00:09:38.340 --> 00:09:39.609
Yes? Good.

00:09:40.475 --> 00:09:44.158
Your regular cup of coffee, 54 degrees C,

00:09:44.182 --> 00:09:46.292
an extra-hot one, well, 60.

00:09:46.854 --> 00:09:49.025
So, put in coffee shop terms,

00:09:49.049 --> 00:09:51.612
the boiling river plots like this.

00:09:52.359 --> 00:09:53.858
There you have your hot coffee.

00:09:54.864 --> 00:09:56.588
Here you have your extra-hot coffee,

00:09:56.612 --> 00:09:58.786
and you can see
that there's a bit point there

00:09:58.810 --> 00:10:01.798
where the river is still hotter
than even the extra-hot coffee.

00:10:01.822 --> 00:10:03.814
And these are average water temperatures.

00:10:03.838 --> 00:10:08.037
We took these in the dry season to ensure
the purest geothermal temperatures.

00:10:08.561 --> 00:10:11.181
But there's a magic number here
that's not being shown,

00:10:11.205 --> 00:10:13.735
and that number is 47 degrees C,

00:10:14.814 --> 00:10:17.336
because that's where things start to hurt,

00:10:17.360 --> 00:10:21.533
and I know this from very
personal experience.

00:10:22.144 --> 00:10:24.970
Above that temperature,
you don't want to get in that water.

00:10:24.994 --> 00:10:26.656
You need to be careful.

00:10:26.680 --> 00:10:27.995
It can be deadly.

00:10:28.662 --> 00:10:30.953
I've seen all sorts of animals fall in,

00:10:30.977 --> 00:10:35.156
and what's shocking to me,
is the process is pretty much the same.

00:10:35.856 --> 00:10:38.537
So they fall in and the first thing
to go are the eyes.

00:10:38.561 --> 00:10:41.928
Eyes, apparently, cook very quickly.
They turn this milky-white color.

00:10:41.952 --> 00:10:43.302
The stream is carrying them.

00:10:43.326 --> 00:10:46.389
They're trying to swim out,
but their meat is cooking on the bone

00:10:46.413 --> 00:10:47.579
because it's so hot.

00:10:47.603 --> 00:10:49.448
So they're losing power, losing power,

00:10:49.472 --> 00:10:52.862
until finally they get to a point
where hot water goes into their mouths

00:10:52.886 --> 00:10:55.107
and they cook from the inside out.

00:10:55.398 --> 00:11:00.630
(Laughter)

00:11:00.654 --> 00:11:02.773
A bit sadistic, aren't we?

00:11:02.797 --> 00:11:04.137
Jeez.

00:11:05.320 --> 00:11:07.938
Leave them marinating for a little longer.

00:11:09.426 --> 00:11:12.154
What's, again, amazing
are these temperatures.

00:11:12.178 --> 00:11:15.656
They're similar to things that I've seen
on volcanoes all over the world

00:11:15.680 --> 00:11:18.217
and even super-volcanoes like Yellowstone.

00:11:18.854 --> 00:11:20.162
But here's the thing:

00:11:22.131 --> 00:11:27.130
the data is showing
that the boiling river exists

00:11:27.154 --> 00:11:29.444
independent of volcanism.

00:11:30.449 --> 00:11:33.869
It's neither magmatic
or volcanic in origin,

00:11:35.680 --> 00:11:41.883
and again, over 700 kilometers away
from the nearest volcanic center.

00:11:42.501 --> 00:11:46.867
How can a boiling river exist like this?

00:11:47.748 --> 00:11:50.904
I've asked geothermal experts
and volcanologists for years,

00:11:50.928 --> 00:11:55.745
and I'm still unable to find another
non-volcanic geothermal system

00:11:55.769 --> 00:11:57.336
of this magnitude.

00:11:59.079 --> 00:12:00.603
It's unique.

00:12:01.447 --> 00:12:04.889
It's special on a global scale.

00:12:06.666 --> 00:12:09.134
So, still -- how does it work?

00:12:10.418 --> 00:12:12.554
Where do we get this heat?

00:12:13.144 --> 00:12:15.237
There's still more research to be done

00:12:15.261 --> 00:12:18.450
to better constrain the problem
and better understand the system,

00:12:18.474 --> 00:12:20.800
but from what the data is telling us now,

00:12:20.824 --> 00:12:24.188
it looks to be the result
of a large hydrothermal system.

00:12:25.109 --> 00:12:26.569
Basically, it works like this:

00:12:26.593 --> 00:12:29.901
So, the deeper you go
into the earth, the hotter it gets.

00:12:29.925 --> 00:12:32.553
We refer to this
as the geothermal gradient.

00:12:33.418 --> 00:12:38.346
The waters could be coming
from as far away as glaciers in the Andes,

00:12:38.370 --> 00:12:40.369
then seeping down deep into the earth

00:12:40.393 --> 00:12:43.160
and coming out to form the boiling river

00:12:43.184 --> 00:12:46.191
after getting heated up
from the geothermal gradient,

00:12:47.269 --> 00:12:49.508
all due to this unique geologic setting.

00:12:50.545 --> 00:12:53.392
Now, we found
that in and around the river --

00:12:53.416 --> 00:12:54.909
this is working with colleagues

00:12:54.933 --> 00:12:57.020
from National Geographic,
Dr. Spencer Wells,

00:12:57.044 --> 00:12:59.754
and Dr. Jon Eisen from UC Davis --

00:12:59.778 --> 00:13:03.040
we genetically sequenced
the extremophile lifeforms

00:13:03.064 --> 00:13:07.668
living in and around the river,
and have found new lifeforms,

00:13:07.692 --> 00:13:11.107
unique species living
in the boiling river.

00:13:12.222 --> 00:13:17.465
But again, despite all of these studies,
all of these discoveries and the legends,

00:13:18.457 --> 00:13:19.457
a question remains:

00:13:21.662 --> 00:13:24.582
What is the significance
of the boiling river?

00:13:26.559 --> 00:13:31.205
What is the significance
of this stationary cloud

00:13:31.229 --> 00:13:34.105
that always hovers
over this patch of jungle?

00:13:35.291 --> 00:13:37.941
And what is the significance

00:13:37.965 --> 00:13:40.948
of a detail in a childhood legend?

00:13:43.505 --> 00:13:46.613
To the shaman and his community,
it's a sacred site.

00:13:47.372 --> 00:13:49.717
To me, as a geoscientist,

00:13:49.741 --> 00:13:52.584
it's a unique geothermal phenomenon.

00:13:54.032 --> 00:13:57.730
But to the illegal loggers
and cattle farmers,

00:13:57.754 --> 00:14:01.397
it's just another resource to exploit.

00:14:02.778 --> 00:14:06.565
And to the Peruvian government,
it's just another stretch

00:14:06.589 --> 00:14:12.533
of unprotected land ready for development.

00:14:14.144 --> 00:14:17.740
My goal is to ensure
that whoever controls this land

00:14:17.764 --> 00:14:21.882
understands the boiling river's
uniqueness and significance.

00:14:22.850 --> 00:14:24.588
Because that's the question,

00:14:25.811 --> 00:14:27.445
one of significance.

00:14:28.526 --> 00:14:30.855
And the thing there is,

title: A simple way to break a bad habit
transcript: When I was first learning to meditate, the instruction was to simply pay attention to my breath, and when my mind wandered, to bring it back.Sounded simple enough. Yet I'd sit on these silent retreats, sweating through T-shirts in the middle of winter. I'd take naps every chance I got because it was really hard work. Actually, it was exhausting. The instruction was simple enough but I was missing something really important.So why is it so hard to pay attention? Well, studies show that even when we're really trying to pay attention to something — like maybe this talk — at some point, about half of us will drift off into a daydream, or have this urge to check our Twitter feed.So what's going on here? It turns out that we're fighting one of the most evolutionarily-conserved learning processes currently known in science, one that's conserved back to the most basic nervous systems known to man.This reward-based learning process is called positive and negative reinforcement, and basically goes like this. We see some food that looks good, our brain says, "Calories! ... Survival!" We eat the food, we taste it — it tastes good. And especially with sugar, our bodies send a signal to our brain that says, "Remember what you're eating and where you found it." We lay down this context-dependent memory and learn to repeat the process next time. See food, eat food, feel good, repeat. Trigger, behavior, reward.Simple, right? Well, after a while, our creative brains say, "You know what? You can use this for more than just remembering where food is. You know, next time you feel bad, why don't you try eating something good so you'll feel better?" We thank our brains for the great idea, try this and quickly learn that if we eat chocolate or ice cream when we're mad or sad, we feel better.Same process, just a different trigger. Instead of this hunger signal coming from our stomach, this emotional signal — feeling sad — triggers that urge to eat.Maybe in our teenage years, we were a nerd at school, and we see those rebel kids outside smoking and we think, "Hey, I want to be cool." So we start smoking. The Marlboro Man wasn't a dork, and that was no accident. See cool, smoke to be cool, feel good. Repeat. Trigger, behavior, reward. And each time we do this, we learn to repeat the process and it becomes a habit. So later, feeling stressed out triggers that urge to smoke a cigarette or to eat something sweet.Now, with these same brain processes, we've gone from learning to survive to literally killing ourselves with these habits. Obesity and smoking are among the leading preventable causes of morbidity and mortality in the world.So back to my breath. What if instead of fighting our brains, or trying to force ourselves to pay attention, we instead tapped into this natural, reward-based learning process ... but added a twist? What if instead we just got really curious about what was happening in our momentary experience?I'll give you an example. In my lab, we studied whether mindfulness training could help people quit smoking. Now, just like trying to force myself to pay attention to my breath, they could try to force themselves to quit smoking. And the majority of them had tried this before and failed — on average, six times.Now, with mindfulness training, we dropped the bit about forcing and instead focused on being curious. In fact, we even told them to smoke. What? Yeah, we said, "Go ahead and smoke, just be really curious about what it's like when you do."And what did they notice? Well here's an example from one of our smokers. She said, "Mindful smoking: smells like stinky cheese and tastes like chemicals, YUCK!" Now, she knew, cognitively that smoking was bad for her, that's why she joined our program. What she discovered just by being curiously aware when she smoked was that smoking tastes like shit.(Laughter)Now, she moved from knowledge to wisdom. She moved from knowing in her head that smoking was bad for her to knowing it in her bones, and the spell of smoking was broken. She started to become disenchanted with her behavior.Now, the prefrontal cortex, that youngest part of our brain from an evolutionary perspective, it understands on an intellectual level that we shouldn't smoke. And it tries its hardest to help us change our behavior, to help us stop smoking, to help us stop eating that second, that third, that fourth cookie. We call this cognitive control. We're using cognition to control our behavior. Unfortunately, this is also the first part of our brain that goes offline when we get stressed out, which isn't that helpful.Now, we can all relate to this in our own experience. We're much more likely to do things like yell at our spouse or kids when we're stressed out or tired, even though we know it's not going to be helpful. We just can't help ourselves.When the prefrontal cortex goes offline, we fall back into our old habits, which is why this disenchantment is so important. Seeing what we get from our habits helps us understand them at a deeper level — to know it in our bones so we don't have to force ourselves to hold back or restrain ourselves from behavior. We're just less interested in doing it in the first place.And this is what mindfulness is all about: Seeing really clearly what we get when we get caught up in our behaviors, becoming disenchanted on a visceral level and from this disenchanted stance, naturally letting go.This isn't to say that, poof, magically we quit smoking. But over time, as we learn to see more and more clearly the results of our actions, we let go of old habits and form new ones.The paradox here is that mindfulness is just about being really interested in getting close and personal with what's actually happening in our bodies and minds from moment to moment. This willingness to turn toward our experience rather than trying to make unpleasant cravings go away as quickly as possible. And this willingness to turn toward our experience is supported by curiosity, which is naturally rewarding.What does curiosity feel like? It feels good. And what happens when we get curious? We start to notice that cravings are simply made up of body sensations — oh, there's tightness, there's tension, there's restlessness — and that these body sensations come and go. These are bite-size pieces of experiences that we can manage from moment to moment rather than getting clobbered by this huge, scary craving that we choke on.In other words, when we get curious, we step out of our old, fear-based, reactive habit patterns, and we step into being. We become this inner scientist where we're eagerly awaiting that next data point.Now, this might sound too simplistic to affect behavior. But in one study, we found that mindfulness training was twice as good as gold standard therapy at helping people quit smoking. So it actually works.And when we studied the brains of experienced meditators, we found that parts of a neural network of self-referential processing called the default mode network were at play. Now, one current hypothesis is that a region of this network, called the posterior cingulate cortex, is activated not necessarily by craving itself but when we get caught up in it, when we get sucked in, and it takes us for a ride.In contrast, when we let go — step out of the process just by being curiously aware of what's happening — this same brain region quiets down.Now we're testing app and online-based mindfulness training programs that target these core mechanisms and, ironically, use the same technology that's driving us to distraction to help us step out of our unhealthy habit patterns of smoking, of stress eating and other addictive behaviors.Now, remember that bit about context-dependent memory? We can deliver these tools to peoples' fingertips in the contexts that matter most. So we can help them tap into their inherent capacity to be curiously aware right when that urge to smoke or stress eat or whatever arises.So if you don't smoke or stress eat, maybe the next time you feel this urge to check your email when you're bored, or you're trying to distract yourself from work, or maybe to compulsively respond to that text message when you're driving, see if you can tap into this natural capacity, just be curiously aware of what's happening in your body and mind in that moment. It will just be another chance to perpetuate one of our endless and exhaustive habit loops ... or step out of it.Instead of see text message, compulsively text back, feel a little bit better — notice the urge, get curious, feel the joy of letting go and repeat.Thank you.(Applause)
